title: tory says government cant stop
story: Tory says government cant stop PO Ferries sackings despite claims they broke the lawMinister James Heappey said it was a commercial decision to sack  crew over video call with no notice - despite the Mirror understanding the government is still looking PO Ferries actions were lawfulThe PO ferry Pride of Hull in the Port of Hull, East Yorkshire, as the ferry operator suspended sailings and handed  seafarers immediate severance notices Image: PAByDan BloomOnline Political EditorRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA top Tory today suggested the government can do nothing to stop the PO Ferries scandal despite a union chief claiming the firm broke the law.James Heappey said the firm made a “commercial decision” to sack  staff with no notice - replacing them with agency staff - over a video call yesterday.Security guards, some allegedly with handcuffs and balaclavas, were reportedly hired to clear crew from the vessels, said union Nautilus International. The minister said the firm’s actions were “disgraceful” and “absolutely horrendous”, but told Sky News: “Sadly it is the case that the government cannot force an employer to continue to employ people that the employer has said it doesn’t want to employ.” The Mirror understands the government is still looking into whether PO Ferries’ actions were lawful. Ministers have asked officials to liaise with the Insolvency Service to checkthe firm notied it in advance - a legal requirement.But Mr Heappey’s comments came amid mounting outrage and pressure on Boris Johnson to step in. Labour has written to the Prime Minister demanding he “stands up for loyal workers in Britain”. Since this story was published, the government has said it is looking into whether the firm broke the law. Read the updated story here. Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh, who is visiting sacked staff at Dover, called on the PM to suspend contracts and licences of PO Ferries’ owner DP World until the matter is resolved. She also demanded the company’s removal from the UK Government’s Transport Advisory Group. Demonstrations against the mass redundancies are taking place at Dover, Liverpool and Hull today. Firms are required by law to noty the Insolvency Service - and consult with staff -they plan to make more than  staff redundant at a single site. If there are  to  redundancies at a site, they must noty the Insolvency Service and start a consultation at least  days before the first dismissal. If there are  or more redundancies at a site, they must noty the Insolvency Service and start a consultation at least  days in advance. RMT union general secretary Mick Lynch claimed PO Ferries had “flagrantly broken the law, deliberately”. He told LBC’s Tonight with Andrew Marr: “The way you break the law is by not informing the [Business] department or the transport minister - they have to fill out an HR form to make redundancies. “They have to give  or  days’ notice of that consultation and you work through the trade unions and the reps what you’re going to do about this situation.” A union source told the Mirror union officials are % sure the action was unlawful, in their opinion, and are looking into the situation. Asked againit was legal, Armed Forces minister Mr Heappey told the BBC : “I’m not absolutely clear on that exact issue you raised, forgive me, my expertise is within the Ministry of Defence.“But I wasn’t aware there was any suggestion that it was illegal. I think it’s grubby.” He added: Ultimately, it is not something the Government can stop PO from doing. Now the focus will be on supporting those who have lost their jobs. Meanwhile Boris Johnson faces demands to spell out exactly when he knew about the sackings. Transport Minister Robert Courts said the government found out about the impending sackings on Wednesday evening. Mr Lynch fumed: “He knew this last night and didn’t tell anyone. “The Department For Transport knew this was happening and they knew they were going to break the law.”  PO Ferries owner DP World is majority-owned by the Dubai Sovereign Wealth Fund and, therefore, ultimately by the Dubai Royal Family. Last night a minister failed to sayBoris Johnson discussed the issue on a trip to the United Arab Emirates on Wednesday morning. No today said only a tight circle of officials in the Department for Transport knew on Wednesday night, and could not say when the PM found out. The PMaposs spokesman denied PO was raised in his meeting with the Crown Prince of the UAE on Wednesday, though could not immediately confirm the issue did not come up at all, in any way during the trip.Labour today demanded the Prime Minister answer whether “anyone” raised the issue on his trip to the UAE, of which Dubai is a part. Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh said: “This was a despicable assault on workers’ rights. “But British seafarers do not need meaningless platitudes - they need action. After the PM failed to get an agreement to ramp up oil production, she added: “Boris Johnson went to the UAE with a begging bowl, and as he ed eight hundred British workers were sacked without notice by one of their investment arms. “The Government must now stand up for loyal workers in Britain being undermined by overseas billionaires.” Tory ministers have faced a furious backlash as the scandal erupted just five months after they killed off a bid to outlaw ‘ fire and rehire’.Labour MP Barry Gardiner tried to ban the practice of firms sacking staff, then hiring them back on worse terms and conditions. His Employment and Trade Union RightsBill would have made it it easier to fight the tactic at a tribunal. It would have also restricted firmsapos ability to y terms through a contract, and force them to consult on changes for  or more employees. But Tory ministers blocked attempts to force a vote on the Bill, talking beyond a .pm cut-off time under arcane Commons rules. Mr Gardiner said last night: “The disgraceful actions taken by PO against their  seafarers shows yet again how employers are abusing the laws around fire and rehire. “The culture of insecurity treats workers as nothing more than a digit on a balance sheet is becoming normalised by both greedy businesses who are emboldened by governments.” A Whitehall source hit back that PO Ferries’ actions did not appear to be a case of fire and rehire. They said instead the firm appeared to be firing staff to hire dferent people on less money. Labour MP Diana Johnson said staff were sacked “immediately” to be replaced by “agency staff mainly from overseas”, waiting in buses by the quayside.This is shameful and it goes against all norms of fair and reasonable behaviour,” she told the Commons. “Itaposs clear that foreign ratings will be employed on terms that are less favourable than our current UK seafarers are. And this is about a race to the bottom in terms and conditions reminiscent of the worst Thatcherite policies.” The Tory chair of the Commons Transport Select Committee, Huw Merriman, said the news was deeply concerning. Firing loyal staff and replacing them with cheaper labour sourced from where is not a model that the public will wear,” he said. “That model was not acceptable when our national flag carrier airline attempted to adopt it, and it is not acceptable now.” Announcing the decision on Thursday, the ferry operator, bought by Dubai-based logistics giant DP World in , insisted the decision to cut jobs was very dficult but necessary as it was not a viable business in its current state. It said in a statement: We have made a £ million loss year-on-year, which has been covered by our parent, DP World. This is not sustainable. Our survival is dependent on making swt and signicant changes now. Without these changes there is no future for PO Ferries. A PO spokesperson said: “All affected crew who worked yesterday were notied face-to-face and in-person, on board their vessels. “For crew who were rostered off, PO Ferries made all efforts to noty them personally: Virtual meetings were held, they were also inidually telephoned, plus email and SMS notications were sent before dismissal letters and severance terms were shared via courier and email. “For any crew members we did not reach personally despite this cascade of steps, regretfully the news of their dismissal must have come as a shock and we apologise for this. title: dog trust issues finds peace
story: Dog with trust issues finds peace watching David Attenborough documentariesOne-year-old Freya was incredibly luck to survive being thrown from a truck travelling at high speed - but has become extremely nervous since the incident and is struggling to settle into kennelsFreya, a one-year-old terrier crossByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Mar |commentsA tiny dog has been left with trust issues after being thrown from a truck travelling at mph.But the terrier cross has found solace in watching David Attenborough nature documentaries.One-year-old Freya was saved by members of the public who saw her being thrown from a vehicle travelling along Benover Road in Yalding, Kent, on January . RSPCA Inspector Kirsten Ormerod, who is investigating the incident, said: “Freya was incredibly lucky to survive after being thrown from a truck travelling at mph.Witnesses who saw the shocking incident said she was thrown with such force that she landed on the opposite side of the road, and the vehicle didn’t even slow down.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.“Some wonderful people who saw the events unfold rushed her to a local vet and contacted us to report the incident. Vets took Freya into surgery to check for any internal injuries but, amazingly, she came out of the incident relatively unscathed.“She’s now being cared for by RSPCA staff at one of our centres and is doing really well but is finding kennel le stressful. Unsurprisingly, given everything she has been through, she is very nervous and kennels are just too overwhelming for her.“We moved Freya into her own private area of the kennels which is much quieter and calmer, and we’ve discovered that she loves nature documentaries so she has her own TV which is always playing David Attenborough programmes in the background. They seem to soothe her and help her relax! “I’ve popped in to see her a few times and when I have case work and paperwork to do I often go and sit with her, have a cuddle and watch Blue Planet, which is her favourite. She just enjoys being with you.” The RSPCA continues to investigate who is responsible for abandoning Freya in such a horric act of cruelty and is appealing for anyone with information to contact the appeal line on    and leave a message for Inspector Ormerod.If you’re interested in offering an RSPCA rescue dog a new home please visit www.rspca.org.uk findapet. To help the RSPCA continue rescuing, rehabilitating and rehoming animals in desperate need of care, like Freya, as well as investigating animal cruelty, please donate by visiting our website or calling our donation line on   .Do you have a dog story to share  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. news uk-news drivers-parking-pavements-face-being-"Martin Lewis explains council and private company parking finesByRachel PughFelix ReevesKieren Williams:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsParking is becoming increasingly hard to find in boroughs across London and England, as a whole. Now, drivers in England may face a £ for bad parking under a new law that may come into force soon. Under new plans drawn up, fixed penalty notices could be given out to those who park on the street, eventhere’s no double yellow lines.If the laws pass through parliament, and drivers park up on a pavement, blocking a narrow road or the pathway itself, they could risk the £ fine. This comes as a quarter of motorists said they were unsure of the rules around parking on pavements,Manchester Evening News reported .New laws around parking on pavements are one of many coming into power this year. And as well as facing fines, drivers caught breaking the new laws could be hit with points on their license too.  Some of these changes are still under consultation in England and Wales, but it is believed that local councils will have more power when it comes to fining reckless parkers. However, parking on pavements is already illegal in London and some other parts of the UK. Scotland’s rulings are expected to come into force in . Whilst some drivers may wrongly think parking on the pavement is fine, and barely an offence, the paths are there for the safety of pedestrians. If blocked, pedestrians might be forced to walk around in the road, which is jeopardises their safety.  Alex Kindred, car insurance expert at Confused, told the MEN: “What may seem a small inconvenience to some, might be a huge hindrance to others. “But it’s important to remember that pavements are there for the use and safety of pedestrians only, and therefore should be respected by all other road users. “However, without a clearer understanding of the law around pavement parking, it’ll be hard to implement fines to drivers who break the rules. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  “The current laws around pavement parking can be quite confusing, which is why it’s dficult at times to prosecute drivers. “With consultations ongoing for England and Wales, with Scotland already pioneering the way to make a big change, drivers should be wary that changes could come into force sooner rather than later. “Councils will be given a bigger responsibility and penalty charges could be issued. “The laws around parking on pavements is just one of many new driving laws coming into effect this year, with road user safety at the forefront of each.”  More than  percent of drivers said they have had to park on a pavement in the past, with more than two in five saying they felt danger in doing so. The issue can be particularly dangerous for children and those with disabilities. A number of changes were made in the Highway Code recently which aims to protect all road users from unnecessary danger.  One of the rules involved pavements and the potential danger cyclists and pedestrians face when travelling down them. Rule  of the Highway Code states: “When using an electric vehicle charge point, you should park close to the charge point and avoid creating a trip hazard for pedestrians from trailing cables. “Display a warning signyou can. After using the charge point, you shouldcharging cables and connectors neatly to minimise the danger to pedestrians and avoid creating an obstacle for other road users.” Key pavement parking rules to watch out for Amid all of the new driving rules and laws being introduced in , these are thew three key pavement parking rules for drivers across England to look out for.Avoid parking on the pavementUnless there is a sign that explicitly says you are allowed to park your vehicle on the pavement, this should generally be avoided. Highway Code Rule  states: You MUST NOT park partially or wholly on the pavement in London, and should not do so where unless signs permit it.Parking on the pavement can obstruct and seriously inconvenience pedestrians, people in wheelchairs or with visual impairments and people with prams or pushchairs. Follow the pavement parking signs If the road you are parking on has a blue and white sign showing a car on the pavement, you are permitted to park on the pavement in that zone. This means that will not be fined for doing so.Avoid parking on the pavement outside your house Contrary to popular belief, unless you live on a private road the pavement outside your home belongs to the council. Therefore, youaposll still be slapped with fines for breaking parking rules.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Highways England" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: exact time mini heatwave ending
story: Exact time mini-heatwave is ending this weekend according to Met OfficeIn a rare treat, Brits are about to blasted with glorious warm air from Northern Africa that could make temperatures DOUBLE the normal March average - heres what you need to knowGrab the sun tan lotion, its time for the annual weekend of spring pretending to be summer Image: Adam Gerrard   Sunday MirrorByHarry ThompsonTrends Writer:,  Mar |comments The Met Office has given an update on when the mini-heatwave over the weekend is due to end.Predictions from the forecaster said the UK could enjoy its hottest day of the year this weekend, with temperatures due to hit a balmy  to  degrees. The summery stint is caused by a huge band of high pressure carrying with it a pocket of air from North Africa, keeping conditions appealing for those looking to shake off their winter layers for a day or two. Met Office meteorologist Clare Nasir said: Generally the weekend is looking fine and dry, much warmer with some sunshine. High pressure reaching across Denmark will allow for settled conditions to extend right across the UK, but some stronger winds on Saturday certainly. “Gusts over the hills and moors as well as the mountains, but with a southerly wind it will feel very warm across some parts, particularly I would say the Moray Firth where we could see an C.But enjoy the good times while they last, because before you know it the summer in spring will come to an end, with the British Isles set toto slightly more seasonal weather.When does the mini-heatwave end   The mini-heatwave is due to end on Sunday March , so lap up those rays while you have the chance. The Met Office has published an overview of the weather expected over the weekend. It says: Chance of rain, most likely in the east, from Sunday. Turning colder through Sunday. To make things worse, when this little sunspot passes, it will be a while until we get another. The Met Office long-range forecast from Tuesday says: “There is likely to be iable cloud cover, most extensive in the south with the chance of some patchy light rain. Temperatures likely to be around normal, after a cold start. But don’t let this get you down - the weekend ahead looks fantastic, with temperatures well above the average. While you sun yourself in the glory of -degree heat, remember that the average temperature for March is only C. Describing Saturday’s weather, the Met Office added: “Fine, dry and bright with plenty of sunshine, but also windy, especially in the south and west. Feeling pleasantly warm in the sunshine out of the wind.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeHeatwave" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: food blogger jack monroe shares
story: Food blogger Jack Monroe shares easy p meal as cost of living crisis hitsFood campaigner Jack Monroe has made a "delicious" meal that she says costs just  pence as she comes up with budget recipes to help people struggling with the cost of living crisisJack Monroe has made a meal costing just  pence Image: Steve BainbridgeByBen ReidTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsFood campaigner Jack Monroe has made a delicious meal that costs just  pence as she gives ideas to people who are struggling in the cost of living crisis.Prices have been soaring with inflation and now fuel and energy prices are being hit further by the war in the Ukraine, making it dficult for some people in the UK to make ends meet. It has become vital for families to watch their budgets and come up with dferent ways that they can cut costs, reported NottinghamshireLive.With that in mind, anti-poverty campaigner Jack Monroe often details money-saving recipes for her followers to enjoy.She posts money-saving recipes on her website cookingonabootstrap to help those watching their budget, as well as on her Instagram. One of the easiest and healthiest foods she has posted is in a recipe which costs just  pence per portion to make and could provide an easy lunch for people. The red lentil, carrot and onion dip is incredibly cheap to make and when served with pitta bread can make a simple and tasty lunch for next to nothing. Jack describes the recipe as a delicious and enjoyable way to sneak some veggies in using just a handful of simple store cupboard ingredients and basic ingredients. The recipe is advised to serve four - but this is just a guideline as Jack says she polished off a bowl to herself when trying it out.The dip will keep in the fridge when covered or put in a container for up to three days.And fans have taken to social media to say how much they like the budget meal. One fan on Instagram responded: Will it last  days in the fridge though  Suspect it will be eaten well before then! Looks yummy and easy to do! Looks absolutely delish Jack, thank you for sharing, said another. I have all of these things!! I never have all of the things! I know what Iaposm having for lunch tomorrow then, added a third. A fourth wrote: Another perfect recipe, thank you. You can check out the recipe below in the Instagram post by swiping. title: huge queues ports demos held
story: PO sackings spark queues and chaos at ports with some routes cancelled for  daysDover and Hull are among the ports that have descended into chaos with huge queues having built up with confused passengers and protesters after  PO staff were ruthlessly sackedPO ferries sacked  workers on Thursday Image: PAByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsMassive queues built up at ports including Dover and Hull with protests and confused travellers after PO ruthlessly sacked hundreds of staff, leaving some routes cancelled for ten days.The  workers were sacked immediately, with no notice, and are set to be replaced by agency workers, leading to services halting at am on Thursday.Security guards wearing balaclavas boarded ships with handcuffs to remove fired crew, it was alleged.It led to widespread confusion at ports with passengers taken off ferries and told to await information amidst rumours they would need to use other services. Furious passengers were initially told routes would be cancelled for a few days but then by up to  days as they locate new crews, it was reported. Were you caught up in the chaos  Email webnews@mirror  A van driver said the situation was an absolute nightmare with no information.Workers have told how they were given five minutes to get their stuff and get off the ship, reported The Sun, with security guards wearing balaclavas came on board to remove people.A dad said PO was “stabbing us in the back” and that he had to switch off the call where he was told he was being sacked. They claim the firm is running at a £ million loss but DP World who run it from Dubai is thriving, he said. “What they want is British seafarers gone as they see us as too expensive. The new foreign workers are already on board.And I’ve got nothing against them. But clearly the company has been planning this behind our backs for a long time. It’s not fair.  “We should have been given notice. Not half an hour.” Another -year-old engineer who has worked on ferries for over  years said: “This is no way to treat people. “I’ve seen coachloads of agency crews waiting in the car park at Hythe services in Kent, just waiting to come down.” Images from motorway cameras on the M and the M suggest the queues have cleared up this morning. Crew members of the Pride of Hull staged a protest after hearing news of their redundancies, refusing to get off the ship as instructed.RMT member and regional organiser for Yorkshire and Lincolnshire, Gaz Jackson, shared several video updates during the sit-in. At around am said of the stand-off: Weaposve got a real situation going on on the ground. Weaposve got a coachload of Filipino ratings waiting to take over from our British crew and also a coachload of heavy hands that are supposed to be handcuff-trained. So Iaposm expecting us to be lynched off this vessel, but me and other members are going to stay on here as long as it takes to get this situation resolved. The shipaposs Captain, Dutchman Eugene Favier, said he would refuse to let police on boardthey attempted.When he left the ship to talk to management, agency staff boarded and the sit in was brought to a close at around .pm.  Unions and politicians condemned the move, blamed by the company on losses of £ million following the slump in travel because of the pandemic. The Rail, Maritime and Transport unionis seeking legal advice to challenge the sackings. It said the UK has seen one of the most “vicious examples of despotic employer behaviour” and one of the most shameful episodes in its recent industrial history. Announcing the decision on Thursday, the ferry operator, bought by Dubai-based logistics giant DP World in , insisted the decision to cut jobs was “very dficult but necessary” as it was “not a viable business” in its current state. The union called for mass trade union and wider public support for demonstrations in Dover, Liverpool and Hull on Friday.  In a message to RMT members, general secretary Mick Lynch said: “It was with deep shock that I learned the news of the wholesale job cuts taking place at PO Ferries, but I am sure that my shock was nothing as compared to the devastation this news brought to you and your colleagues. “PO’s decision to lay off  workers is a kick in the teeth to the hard-working members of staff who have kept the business running through the global health crisis. “The RMT has received reports that security guards at Dover have boarded ships with handcuffs to remove crew so they can be replaced with cheaper labour. This union is horried that PO Ferries can treat their loyal workforce in such a despicable manner. “PO Ferries claimed almost £ million in Government grants in , which included furlough payments for its employees. PO is owned by DP World, the multi-national ports and logistics company based in Dubai. It paid a £ million idend to shareholders in . “This appalling situation has arisen as a result of DP World wishing to maximise their profits and the failure of the Government to intervene and protect the jobs of you and your colleagues. “Your union is seeking advice on what legal action can be taken.”  Mark Dickinson of Nautilus International said there are serious safety concerns around the decision to replace the seafarers with agency workers.He told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: There are serious safety concerns, which is why the company cannot reintroduce services with the lower-paid agency crew that theyaposve recruited via this company called International Ferry Management of Malta.Mr Dickinson said the Maritime Coastguard Agency must be absolutely clear and confident that those new crew, unfamiliar with the vessels, unfamiliar with the routes, with the berths can operate ships safely.He added: This is an intensely worrying situation.Weaposve written to the Maritime Coastguard Agency and we hope and we pray that they will do their job.I know they will. They will do their job and make sure the ships are safe. He added: It is a dark day in the shipping industry. Iaposve been in this game for over  years and Iaposve seen some curveballs and some shocking developments over that time, but this is a new low for a shipping company.To treat the due legal process in such an underhand and callous way has shocked me, taken my breath away. Conservative MP Huw Merriman, chairman of the Transport Select Committee, said PO had made “an appalling error”. “If they do not reverse immediately and reinstate the employees and follow proper process, it’s hard to see a way back for them commercially,” he said. “The parent DP World needs to understand that the British public will not do business with companies who treat their employees with such contempt.” Shadow transport secretary Louise Haigh said: “This is not a corporate restructure. It’s not the way we go about business in this country. “It is beneath contempt the action of thugs.” PO Ferries said in a statement: “We have made a £ million loss year-on-year, which has been covered by our parent, DP World. This is not sustainable. “Our survival is dependent on making swt and signicant changes now. Without these changes there is no future for PO Ferries.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON RMT unionPO FerriesJob lossesRedundancy" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside house sale first time
story: Inside house for sale for first time in  years - virtually untouched since sVirtually untouched three-bedroom s home hits the market in Bristol and still has all its original period features. The previous owner lived at the house until she was The house is being sold with no chain and the asking price is £,ByMark TaylorSport ReporterSamantha Mordi:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA house has gone up for sale for the first time in  years - and is virtually untouched from when it was first built. Estate agents have said the house has alcove shelving, ceiling roses and a larder cupboard in the kitchen reminiscent of s interior design.The home based in the South West, boats three bedrooms and a tiered garden at the back, the Bristol Post reports.And that is not all, the former owners were keen travellers and active into their centenarian years. The house on Hengrove Lane is being marketed by MG estate agents as a striking terraced home bursting with potential.  It’s also close to local amenities, a primary school and thereaposs a sports ground in proximity. Upstairs, there are three bedrooms, two of which are doubles, and a bathroom. There is a large front garden and a tiered garden at the back. According to Kat Wills, marketing manager of MG Estate Agents of Whitchurch, the previous owner lived at the house until she was .  “The previous owners didn’t have any children but we understand the couple were very active into their old age. They were keen travellers and went on many adventures around the world.“The lady’s husband worked for the BBC and he was still playing tennis into his seventies.The lady was apparently a talented musician who studied at the Royal Academy of Music.  She used to hold piano lessons in the front room. “The lived in the house from the s. A lot of the décor is actually the original décor from when they moved in.” The unique house, which looks asit is stuck in time, is being sold with no chain and the asking price is £,, according to the estate agents. title: inside secret bunker could withstand
story: Inside secret bunker that could withstand nuclear attack on sale for £kThe former bunker was built in  to monitor fallouts from any future nuclear attacks on the country. It was designed for three people and has an underground monitoring roomThe former bunker was built in ByDarren McConachieGraeme Murray:,  Mar |comments An incredible secret bunker that could withstand a nuclear weapons attack has gone on sale for £,.Ardgathen Croft, which is hidden beneath the ground in a field, offers future buyers the rare opportunity to own a piece of history. The former bunker was built in  to monitor fallouts from any future nuclear attacks on the country. It was designed to accommodate three people and features an underground monitoring room and chemical toilet. Fortunately it was never required to fill its nuclear war role but was active for thirty years before being closed in . At the time, the UK Government felt that international relations had changed radically and cancelled their plans for upgrading the bunker.  Future Property Auctions has now revealed the aposextremely rare listingapos in in Alford, Aberdeenshire, will be going up for auction next week - with bids starting at £,. They have listed the commercial building with an estimated guide price of £,. The auctioneer company said: Ardgathen Croft is located beneath a field in the north east of Scotland. The bunker was not required to fulfil its nuclear war role. With international relations having changed radically, the British government cancelled plans for upgrading and is sold on a freehold basis. Opened in  and closed . Located on a low mound on the south side of a field boundary  yards east of an un-named minor road.  There is a local bus service connecting with Aberdeen . All surface features remain intact with some flaking of the khaki paint. There are no padlocks and the hatch is locked internally, it can be opened with a Scottish aposTapos bar key. Internally the post is very neat and tidy with many items remaining including folding table, shelf, cupboard, posters, kettle, saucepan, washing bowl, cleaning materials. The locality provides endless beautul walks, stunning countryside, a iety of outdoor activities, and the Lecht Ski Centre and School is only a  minute drive away.  Prospective buyers have until next Thursdayto register their bid to own the unique piece of history. According to Subterranea Britannica, more than  nuclear bunkers were erected in the UK - with at least  installed in Scotland. The Czech Republic has the largest known nuclear bunker sprawling over , square feet which includes a golf course. news uk-news kate-middleton-broke--year-"Kate Middleton and Prince William watch St Patrick’s Day paradeByEmma RosemurgeyAudience WriterSophie McCabe:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge ed to Cavalry Barracks in Hounslow to celebrate St Patrickaposs day by attending the annual parade, with the st Battalion of the Irish Guards today. It marks the first time Prince William and Kate have been able to attend the event in two years, with the celebrating called off in  due to the pandemic and the parade cancelled in  due to most of the regiment being deployed overseas.This year, the couple picked back up their annual tradition of presenting the gt of sprigs of shamrock to officers and guardsmen who then distribute them across the rank.This is a -year tradition, usually carried out by a female member of the royal family, which began in  with Queen Alexander, and for many years the Queen Mother performed the duty, followed by Princess Anne. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. But, despite this being an incredibly long-running tradition for many years, the the Duchess of Cambridge broke royal tradition in  when she opted to stay home instead of attending the parade. Kate had performed the duty four years a in a row previously, before opting to stay at home with her children, Prince George and Prince Charlotte, leaving William to hand out the sprigs to  members of the st Battalion Irish Guards at Hounslow Cavalry Barracks in west London. Although people were notably disappointed about Kateaposs absence, Company Sergeant Major Carl Laverty said they were conscious that she has family commitments, adding that the lads were ecstatic to have their Colonel present the honours instead. At the time, aides were quick to highlight that it was primarily Williamaposs role as Colonel of the regiment to take part in the ceremony. Male members of the Royal Family have performed the duties on rare occasions. George VI, Earl Alexander of Tunis, the Grand Duke of Luxembourg, the Earl of Cavan and Prince Edward have all taken part in the ceremony. This year, Kate took on the responsibility of presenting the regimentaposs mascot, an Irish wolfhound called Domhnall, with his very own shamrock.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: mum turns purple cold after
story: Mum turns purple with cold and fears for daughter after landlord caps gas supplyShelly Van Damme, who has nine-year-old daughter Skye, struggles with her health on a daily basis as she has severe arthritis in her legs and jaw, as well as fibromyalgia, which worsen signicantly in cold conditionsMiss Van Damme, who uses a wheelchair, has lived at her property in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, for five years Image: GloucestershireLive BPMByKim Horton:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsA mum said claimed she turned purple with cold after her landlord capped her gas supply.Shelly Van Damme, who has nine-year-old daughter Skye, struggles with her health on a daily basis as she has severe arthritis in her legs and jaw, as well as fibromyalgia, which worsen signicantly in cold conditions. Her landlord, Bromford housing association, says it has done all it can to sort the situation out but has been unable to make contact with the -year-old, reports Gloucestershire Live.Miss Van Damme, who uses a wheelchair, has lived at her property in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, for five years. The two-bedroom home has been adapted to her needs which include handrails on the stairs, bedroom and bathroom, along with seating adaptations in the bathroom. She said: “A gas engineer was sent out to cap my gas last month, and I have had to come and stay with my friend. I ache from head to foot. Since staying with my friend, I have only just begun being able to speak again as the cold made me so unwell. “I fell down the stairs in November last year after a vertigo attack. I thought I had damaged my tendons and was sent for an MRI scan. The scan showed I have arthritis and fibromyalgia in my back, neck and shoulders. Recently I was also diagnosed with having arthritis in my jaw and when I do not have heating or hot water it makes my health worse.” Miss Van Damme says her health continued to deteriorate because she had no hot water or heating. Sitting on her bath seat with hot water covering her aching bones is able to give her temporary relief from her pain.  Upset by what was happening, Miss Van Damme’s friend requested both she and her daughter go to stay with her. At this point, the tenant claims her skin was looking bruised and purple from the cold. Miss Van Damme said: “Living in a home with no heating or hot water really affects me. My friend saw how poorly I was and said to me ‘you cannot stay here’. My skin looked bruised and I was going purple with the cold. Due to Miss Van Damme’s ongoing hospital appointments, she missed several visits by the gas engineer to service her boiler. Yet Miss Van Damme says she called Bromford twice to try to reschedule the appointments when the gas supply was capped. She said: “Dates have been made to service the boiler when I was either in hospital or had to go to an appointment in December. “They asked me to call them in the new year, but I knew I had an appointment in January for the MRI so I was waiting for that to come. I called them twice about getting it sorted and never had a call back. “In February I heard a ring at my door and I was in bed poorly. Even with my disabilities, it would have taken time for me to answer the door, but a note was pushed through the door to say they had capped my gas.” Miss Van Damme called Bromford to explain her dficulties and how not having heating and hot water would affect her. She says on two occasions she was promised an engineer to visit that day.  Miss Van Damme said: “When I called back again to see what was happening, I was told the call out for an engineer had not been put on the system. I waited and stayed in as I was expecting someone to come round twice. “By this time my body was purple where I was so cold. They expect you to wait in for hours, in either a morning or afternoon appointment, but my body cannot take it. They have made me ill physically and mentally. They still get their rent and fob tenants off. “My daughter has been late for school because I have not been able to stay in Tewkesbury and been at my friendaposs place in Tuffley. I need my home with the adaptations. Bromford says it was forced to cap the gas after unsuccessful attempts to enter the property. The housing association also says it tried to get in touch with Miss Van Damme by text, phone call and letter.Bromford’s associate director of localities Dave Grinter said:: “One of our central aims is to ensure that all of our customers have a home that is safe, secure, and warm and we have a legal responsibility to carry out regular safety checks including annual gas fire and boiler servicing.“Unfortunately, and for Miss Van Damme’s own safety, we were forced to cap the gas at her property on February  after a number of unsuccessful attempts by letter, text message, and telephone to arrange a suitable time to carry out this essential servicing. “We have continued to try to make contact to resolve the situation and on Fridayour contractor attended but was denied access to the property. We remain committed to finding a solution in the quickest possible manner and would urge the customer to contact Bromford as soon as possible.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON HospitalsArthritisHousing" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news nazanin-zaghari-ratclfe-beams-first-"Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe greeted by her family as she s to UKByMatthew DreschNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsThis is Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfeaposs first selfie with her husband and daughter since landing back in the UK after her six-year nightmare in Iran. The -year-old was pictured smiling with her husband Richard and their daughter Gabriella in front of a bed of daffodils. The mumaposs local MP Tulip Siddiq said it was the familyaposs first selfie after Nazaninaposs release from house arrest in Iran. Tweeting the picture, Labouraposs Mrs Siddiq said the reunited couple spoke with her about Morad Tahbaz, who has not been allowed to leave Iran after being released from prison on furlough. Mrs Siddiq said they were both relentless in their pursuit of justice. Nazanin, a British-Iranian charity worker, landed back on British soil in the early hours of Thursday, along with fellow dual national, Anoosheh Ashoori.  They touched down at RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire shortly after am. Heartwarming pictures showed Nazanin reunited with her husband and daughter for the first time in years. Gabriella was heard asking is that mummy  as Nazanin departed the plane.In a video shared on Instagram by Anoosheh Ashoori’s daughter Elika Ashoori, Gabriella shouted “mummy” as Nazanin walked down the plane’s stairs.The seven-year-old girl was pictured running excitedly around the room and being carried on her mother’s hip.  Tears of joy can be heard as the family were reunited and Nazanin could not stop hugging and showering her daughter with kisses. Her release came after the UK finally agreed to settle a £ million debt dating back to the s.Foreign Office Minister James Cleverly said the Government was working to secure theof Mr Tahbaz, telling BBC Breakfast: He also has American nationality, which has in the eyes of the Iranians - not in ours - made his case more complicated.He added: We will continue to work to secure his release and, obviously, we work in close co-ordination with the US on these issues as well. In a tweet on Thursday evening, Ms Siddiq said: So lovely to have uplting conversations with Richard and Nazanin today.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter They are both relentless in their pursuit of justice and raised the plight of Morad Tahbaz with me. Here I was hoping to sleep for a week... Hereaposs their first family selfie! £NazaninIsFree. One charity worker with experience of hostages has warned there is usually a long journey back to normality following release. Lara Symons, , chief executive of charity Hostage International, said the organisation had helped many trauma hostages.She told the PA news agency: From that experience, weaposve learnt that this is a new journey. This is a long journey. I think when people think about normal le, they think about the le that they led before and, sadly, to some extent, that is not possible. You canapost go back to that because both you as a hostage and your family have been changed quite a lot by the experience. title: nazanin zaghari ratcliffes spirit never
story: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfes spirit never faltered despite all the adversitiesIt is hard to comprehend the torment Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has endured since she was arrested on trumped-up charges by the Iranian authorities - but she can now be reunited with her familyNazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe with her husband Richard Ratclfe when their daughter Gabriella was a baby Image: PAopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Mar |comments For six years Nazanin Zaghari-Ratclfe has dreamed of being freed from her Iranian jail and reunited with her family.That moment has now come true. It is hard to comprehend the torment she has endured since she was arrested on trumped-up charges by the Iranian authorities. Twice she went on hunger strike. Her health suffered. She lost two appeals and had her sentenced increased. Many would have been broken by this adversity but Nazanin’s spirit never faltered. It was matched only by the love, tenacity and dedication of her husband Richard who campaigned tirelessly for her release. They did not deserve to be the pawns in a diplomatic power game between London and Tehran. Nor did they deserve to be let down by Boris Johnson whose blundering prompted Iran to level fresh charges against her. This story was not destined to have a happy ending. The fact that it does is a testament to their resilience and devotion to each other.  No more delays Vladimir Putin’s brutal invasion has created the worst humanitarian disaster in Europe since the Second World War. Almost three million Ukrainians have been forced to leave their homes as they seek sanctuary from the Russian bombardment. That number is set to rise as more people flee the besieged cities in Eastern Ukraine. They are in desperate need of food, clothes and a place to live. The tens of thousands of people who have signed up to the Homes for Ukraine scheme shows that households across Britain are ready to help. The only thing standing in their way is the Government’s delay in carrying out checks. Now is the time for compassion, not cold-hearted box ticking and foot dragging. Foal weather Not even the heavy rain could dampen the spirits of racegoers at Cheltenham. The Met Office is promising better weather today. If only it could forecast a winner… Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeWorld War Nazanin Zaghari-RatclfeBoris JohnsonVladimir PutinIranPoliticsDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: popular teacher sacked college after
story: Popular teacher sacked by college after  YEARS prompting outrage from staffA week of lunchtime protests at several college campuses followed Nina Doran’s dismissal - she had been a lecturer and union representative at the City of Liverpool College for  yearsNina Doran worked as a lecturer in Teacher Education and English at the City of Liverpool College until she was suspended on September  Image: Liverpool EchoByRemy GreasleyCharlie Duffield:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsThe sacking of a teacher who worked at a college for  years has prompted outrage from her former colleagues. Nina Doran worked as a lecturer in Teacher Education and English at the City of Liverpool College until she was suspended on September . The college said there had been a breach of confidence, and she learned should would be sacked. Ms Doran had been working at the college since September .As well as teaching, she was a representative for the Universities and Colleges Union branch at the city college, and would liaise with the UCU’s national office to organise unionised workers during industrial disputeShe told the Liverpool Echo : Because I was out of the workplace, I thought that maybe, maybe the suspension won’t go the whole way to a dismissal.It was all a bit of rollercoaster in the end. It’s just shocking, not being in the workplace and not doing what I do, it takes a lot of getting used to.” Both the college and Ms Doran said she could not go into further detail about the allegations while the appeals process was ongoing.  After Ms Doranaposs dismissal, a week of lunchtime protests at several college campuses followed, with unionised staff stressing she is the fourth union representative to be dismissed from the college in the last eight years. This alleged pattern of sackings led some of her colleagues to claim that her dismissal is part of a broader ide-and-rule policy they say is exercised at the college. In the days following Ms Doran’s dismissal, the City of Liverpool College branch of the UCU tweeted: “We are all shocked to discover that @DoranNina, our branch Liaison Chair, has become just the latest in a string of dismissals of prominent @ucu reps by COLC.  Nina has been dismissed for engaging in legitimate trade union activity, another clear case of trade victimisation.“We also believe that it was strategically timed in order to disrupt a legitimate and legal industrial dispute. COLC has maintained a clear ide-and-rule over UCU for years, the current regime manufacturing a culture of fear and intimidation.”Vicky Blake, President of the Universities and Colleges Union, said: “UCU stands in full support of Nina Doran, a hardworking rep who is now facing dismissal proceedings from her post at City of Liverpool College. Nina is a hardworking rep, who has in good faith worked tirelessly and honestly to promote and defend the interests of UCU members working at the college. “As a union we would like to work constructively and productively with the management team at COLC, for the benefit of all staff and students. Sadly, it appears there is a lack of reciprocity from COLC management in this. “Our reps work hard for members and have faced nothing but antagonising behaviour from this employer, the latest instance of which is represented in the dismissal proceedings against Nina Doran.” A spokesperson for the City of Liverpool College said: “While we are unable to comment on inidual cases, we are always focused on maintaining open dialogue with our trade unions to ensure the views and concerns of our valued team members are listened to and actioned where appropriate. We pride ourselves on our integrity and fairness as an employer, and as such take all of our decisions around staffing very seriously. As this is an ongoing matter, we are unable to make further comment at this time.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchools" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news princess-charlotte-inherit-rare-title-"Kate Middleton has modern parenting approach says expertByEmma RosemurgeyAudience WriterBea Isaacson:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsPrincess Charlotte may only be six years old, but she has already become a firm favourite with royal fans and even made history in . When the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge welcomed their youngest child, Prince Louis, on April , , Charlotte became the first woman in history to keep her place in the line of succession despite having a younger male sibling. But thataposs not all for the young royal, who will one day be sister to the King of England, as she could also inherit an incredibly rare title which has only been used seven times in history, My London reports. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Princess Charlotte could be given the name, the Princess Royal of the United Kingdom - a title which currently belongs to Princess Anne. This name was given to Anne by her mother, the Queen, back in , and will belong to her for the rest of her le, regardless of her familial relations within the monarchy. The title was established by Charles I in  for his daughter, Princess Matilda. The incredibly rare title is exclusively given to the eldest daughter of the monarch, so it is assumed Princess Charlotte will one day be given the title, when her father, Prince William, becomes King himself. Interestingly, the Queen herself missed out on the title of Princess Royal, as the eldest daughter of King George VI, but he was unable to give it to her as it still belonged to Princess Mary, until she died in . Given that she went on to become the Queen - one of only eight in our nationaposs history - she probably didnapost lose sleep over missing out on the title.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: queen firm word upset meghan
story: Queen had firm word with upset Meghan Markle after row about eggsHer Majesty reportedly once took the Duchess of Sussex to one side, over a row about whether a dish contained eggs, telling her: "we dont speak to people like thatThe Queen took Meghan for a quiet talking to Image: Getty ImagesByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Mar |commentsThe Queen was once forced to take the Duchess of Sussex to one side after she got upset over tasting egg in a meal which was supposed to be egg-free, an author has claimed.Itaposs reported that Meghan was sampling dishes to be served at her wedding reception when she got very upset at being told a particular meal had no egg in it. Royal author Katie Nicholl claims Meghan protested that she could taste the ingredient, prompting a quiet talking-to from Her Majesty. Meghan reportedly wanted an egg-free alternative for VIPs following strict diets to be able to enjoy.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.She told Yahooaposs Royal Box : Meghan got very upset when she felt that she could taste egg in a dish when she was told there was no egg in there, and she said, aposNo, I can taste it, I can taste thereaposs egg in this dish.aposKatie went on to say that the Queen walked in while the incident was taking place, and quietly took Meghan to the side. I think there was a bit of an upset when suddenly the Queen walked in, because of course, this was Windsor Castle, this is her home, she continued. And she just quietly took Meghan to the side and said, aposMeghan, in this family we donapost speak to people like that.apos  The incident allegedly took place in the lead up to the royal wedding, in which Prince Harry wed the former actor in St Georgeaposs Chapel at Windsor Castle, on May , .Just under two years later, the couple officially stepped down from their duties as senior members of the royal family, before moving to Canada, and then onto Calornia, United States.Since then, Harry and Meghan have been busy welcoming their second child, daughter Lilibet, and carving out careers for themselves, including signing major deals with Netflix and Spoty.On Thursday, March , a spokesperson for the couple’s foundation Archewell confirmed Meghanaposs long-awaited podcast on Spoty would be released in the summer.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: saharan dust uk coast creates
story: Saharan dust on UK coast creates spectacular orange-purple ripples in the skyThe crazy colours are caused by a phenomenon known as Rayleigh scattering which is because of additional particles in the air. The Saharan dust cloud settled over the UK giving skies an otherworldly orange glowThe breathtaking setting could be Morrocco but it was in fact Cleveleys, near Blackpool, Lancs.ByRyan FaheyNews ReporterTom HaynesLucas CumiskeySamantha Mordi:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments British skies were a rainbow of colour as dust from the Sahara surged across Europe this week.The stunning dust creates spectacular orange-purple ripples in the sky with one photographer lucky to capture it as the sunset.Karl Houghton took pictures and said the rare phenomenon was really nice to see in the upper clouds.He added: The Saharan dust in the upper clouds added some really nice colour, with the breathtaking shots taken in Blackpool. In one picture, a massive conical-shaped sculpture, Maryaposs Shell, looks majestic on the sandy stretch beneath the alien sky. The crazy colours are caused by a phenomenon known as Rayleigh scattering, caused by additional particles in the air. Met Office meteorologist Dan Stroud said: The dust in the atmosphere causes the light to be more refracted, so you get the dominance of the red and orange tinges of the spectrum. The cloud formed when dust from the Sahara Desert was driven up into the air by a weather front dubbed Storm Celia by Spanish authorities. It was then pushed over the Mediterranean before covering parts of France and Spain.Baffled Brits were disgusted when they saw their cars in the early hours of the morning and thought the rain was really dirty.Lola Panic, a student from Deptford, southeast London, told The Mirror her garden chairs had been covered in dust as a result of the bizarre weather. Originally we felt a bit disgusted because of how dirty the rain seemed, said the -year-old. Then we felt slightly scared and confused, didn’t want to leave the house. In fact, none of us has left the house yet. But experts warned that the dust will cause a signicant reduction in air quality. Dr Ryder, who works at the University of Reading, said: The plume is forecast to reach southern England during the early hours of Wednesday, covering areas from Dorset to Suffolk, with the southeast counties, particularly Kent, being the worst affected. “Those up early enough on Wednesday will see the tell-tale red dusty sunrise. This is caused by the dust absorbing blue light from the sun and letting more red light through when the sun is low in the sky. By evening the dust will have moved eastwards towards the Netherlands and Germany., he added. One motorist was shocked when she saw the dusty rainwater first thing in the morning. Donna Deeming, , from Basildon, Essex, was only popping out to grab some milk when she noticed her car was covered in dusty rainwater. I sat in the car and thought aposwhat on earth has happened apos the finance administrator said. It’s only very drizzly here. There have been no downpours as yet, so I wasn’t suresomeone had thrown something on the car orit was from some building work locally. Dr Andy Whittamore - the clinical lead at Asthma UK - warned of the risks posed by Saharan dust. He said: Toxic air can leave people struggling for breath and can cause wheezing, coughing, shortness of breath and even a le-threatening asthma attack, he said. “Saharan dust could pose a serious risk to the . million people in the UK with asthma. news uk-news sainsburys-told-its-gone-far-"Shoppers react to Sainsbury’s Carrots  Chocolate Flavoured HoumousByLucy WilliamsonReporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsSupermarket Sainsburyaposs is being accused of going apostoo farapos with its latest Easter treat.The supermarket found itself in a tight spot after customeraposs found it selling chocolate flavoured houmous. And they were quick to share their opinions online about the isive new product on the Sainsburyaposs shelves. Facebook page Snack News  Reviews shared an image of the new Carrots  Chocolate Flavoured Houmous which is a part of the “Easter Bunny Snacks” range.The food product, which costs £, contains carrot batons and a dip made from cooked chickpeas, golden syrup, sesame seed paste, cocoa powder and concentrated lemon juice. Has Sainsburyaposs gone too far this time  Let us know in the comment section  One said that “this sounds horrible” with a second commenting “not sure how I feel about this…”. A third wrote: “Not a good mix me thinks.” Someone  added: “Just throw the whole world in the bin and be done. Youaposve taken it too far. One shopper tagged a friend and said: “A bit of me tbh...wait I just realised it said chocolate wtf no.On Twitter, the outrage continued.@Amarcow tweeted: I am in utter disbelief , to my dismay my local only stock this now all stores in all the sainsburys across leeds! This is a huge change I’m not ready for after having regular hummus with my meal deal for years! What next   Apricot sausage rolls  ! When will it end! @akil_ said: Why @sainsburys why  Carrot and chocolate flavoured houmous is absolutely VILE. Just stop it. Immediately. Adam Maidment managed to pick up a pack by mistake after thinking it was normal houmous. He said: This is my own stupid fault for not properly looking but why is CHOCOLATE HOUMOUS even a thing  However, some shoppers like the sound of carrots and chocolate houmous. One commented that they “need to buy” with another person adding “oh thataposs my cuppa tea”. You can buy the Carrots  Chocolate Flavoured Houmous in Sainsbury’s stores now or online. Part of the on the go range, the vegan-friendly snack will also be included in the supermarket’s £. meal deal. title: tourist left 4 inches shorter
story: Tourist left  inches shorter after breaking her back on Banzai Mallorca waterslideJenner Proctor had to undergo an emergency spinal fusion in Spain to treat her injuries, and says the damage left her ft ins tall, four inches shorter than her  " height before the accident.Jenner Proctor Image: Champion NewsByNev AylingGraeme Murray:,  Mar |commentsA British tourist who says she was left four inches shorter after smashing her back on a Banzai water slide while on holiday in Spain is fighting for £, compensation. Jenner Proctor, broke her spine at the end of her nightmare holiday in , suffering catastrophic injuries during her descent of the extreme -foot high slide at the Aqualand waterpark, in Mallorca. She had to undergo an emergency spinal fusion in Spain to treat her injuries, and says the damage left her ft ins tall, four inches shorter than her apos  height before the accident. Before the tragedy Ms Proctor , of Leighton Buzzard, Beds, was training to be a teacher, but the accident left her struggling to pay for her course and tore her le apart. She is currently not working. Now she has launched a £, damages claim against Spanish amusement park operators, Aspro Ocio S.A, as well as a firm of Spanish insurers, Liberty Seguros, alleging fault in management of the slide.  One would not expect to use this water slide and come off it with a broken back, said Ms Proctoraposs QC, Katherine Deal, during a hearing at the High Court in London. The issues of liability and compensation for her injuries are both disputed. The -foot Banzai ride is designed to power users down the slide boosted by water jets at the top, with riders then flying across the water when they reach the bottom. Ms Proctor, however, says she wasnapost given proper instruction before beginning her descent down the chute on a bodyboard. And after the accident, Ms Proctor - who was a keen swimmer - said she believed she was thrown off her board before even hitting the water. On top of the gruelling surgery to fuse her spine, she then suffered a recurring septic infection for several months after treatment. Her case reached Londonaposs High Court as lawyers discussed pre-trial issues involving analysis of Spanish law and expert evidence about the use of the water slide. The trial itself is expected to be dealt with in line with Spanish law. Although Ms Proctor has now recovered from her fractured spine, her injury has left a legacy of lasting chronic pain, said her barrister after the short hearing. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-country-hotter-"UK weather chart shows warmer temperatures in days aheadByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |commentsBrit sun lovers can expect balmy temperatures over the coming days that could see it hotter than the south of Spain with highs of C - making it the warmest weekend of the year so far.After a cold start to March, the weather is starting to finally feel a bit more like spring and next week the temperatures are expected to get even warmer. “The weather is really settling down, there is going to be a lot of dry weather, probably for the next week or so,” said BBC weather forecaster Darren Bett.And with highs of C it would mean the UK would enjoy temperatures higher than Malaga on the Costa del Sol where there is also rain expected over the next week.But just before people put their winter coats away, it will be a cold start to Friday morning with a yellow Met Office warning for freezing fog that covers western England and Wales. Under clear skies it will be frosty for much of the country and could dip to -C in Scotland.Fog patches may cause some disruption to travel during the morning rush hour, said theMet Officewith a yellow warning running until .am through western England and Wales.A widespread frost with temperatures dipping down close to freezingnot below, certainly for the glens of Scotland we could see a value of - or -C to start the day, said Met Office forecaster Clare Nasir. We run into this dense fog anywhere from the Midlands, mid-Wales down towards the West Country, central and southern England.  But the temperature will soon rise with warmest temperatures in central and southern England and Wales. Ms Nasir continued: Through the day on Friday plenty of blue sky and plenty of sunshine. The sunshine could turn hazy in the west of Scotland as we see more high cloud there and certainly quite a breeze across the Western Isles. Even so everywhere remains dry through the afternoon and that will really help temperatures up very nicely as we head through the middle part of the day. So temperatures coming in around C or C in Scotland or Northern Ireland. However we could see values peaking around C or C across mid-Wales, down towards the south east of England. That’s the picture on Friday, a bright end to the working week.”  Then on Saturday the warmest temperatures are expected to be in Scotland. Winds coming in from the east or the South East means that the highest temperatures are always going to be across more sheltered western areas,” said Mr Bett, of BBC weather. “It could make C along the coast of north west England but it is up towards the north west Highlands and perhaps in the Moray Firth that temperatures could reach C or C, it could be the warmest day of the year so far.” UK forecast for the next  days Plenty of fine weather today once early fog clears. Today: Early fog patches over parts of Wales, the Midlands and southern England soon lting and clearing. Otherwise, conditions fine and dry with plenty of pleasantly warm sunshine. Breezy in the north and across English Channel coastal areas. Tonight: Quickly turning chilly this evening and then a dry night with mostly clear skies. Breezy as well, especially in the south and west. Saturday: Fine, dry and bright with plenty of sunshine, but also windy, especially in the south and west. Feeling pleasantly warm in the sunshine out of the wind. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Mostly fine and dry with some sunshine. Cloudier in the east with rain and showers moving north, becoming dry on Tuesday. Cooler than recently, but turning warmer again by Tuesday. title: woman horror po leave stranded
story: Womans horror as PO Ferries leave her stranded in Rotterdam without her  teethPO Ferries were in crisis last night after  crew members were cruelly sacked over Zoom, while travellers were stranded abroad, including one woman who was left without her  teethThe blunder occurred after PO sacked  employeesByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A customer of PO Ferries who was left stranded after the firm sacked all of its crew was left without her  teeth after herferry didnapost turn up. It comes as the company brutally made  of its crew redundant via video-call and replaced them with cheaper agency workers.The knock-on effect left customers stranded abroad and scrambling to get home after the company suspended some services for  days. One TikTok user shared a video from Rotterdam, where her friend Heidi had been left without her  teeth, after travelling from Hull, only for their ing service not to turn up. In a video, she said: PO havenapost turned up and Heidi has left her teeth on the boat.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here She added in a caption: This trip couldnapost get any worse, sheaposs left her teeth on the boat. People were left in stitches, with one viewer writing: Well at least you canapost say that PO are toothless. Another outraged viewer wrote: They should have left you to get your stuff since they have been made redundant. A third added: Good on you for turning a bad thing into a funny thing, I hope [she] gets her gnashers back. Happily, Heidi was reunited with her teeth a day later - with a TikTok video capturing her jubilation at being reunited with her gnashers. She can be heard exclaiming Oh my god, my teeth. Flippinaposeck, the panic about that was unbelievable. It comes as a captain of a giant PO ferry travelling between Rotterdam and Hull was hailed a hero after drawing up his gangplanks and refusing to allow police or new crewmen to board his vessel. The captain of the Pride of Hull, understood to be Eugene Favier, sealed himself and his crew inside the ferry in the Port of Hull just hours after P announced mass redundancies. The ship normally carries a crew of  people aboard and is one of the biggest ferries in Europe - makes regular crossings between Hull and the Dutch port of Rotterdam. The sit-in was resolved yesterday as the crew were photographed leaving the boat in the afternoon. Read more Gaz Jackson, a regional organiser for the National Union of Rail Maritime and Transport Workers, said negotiations had come to an end when the company agreed to provide paperwork requested by the union. The shipping giant blamed mounting losses, saying: We have made a £million loss year on year which has been covered by our parent, DP World. This is not sustainable. PO cut around , staff during the pandemic, while claiming almost £million in government grants in , including furlough payments. Yet group revenues at owner DP World jumped to £.billion last year, while profits hit £.billion. title: boy 13 behind wheel truck
story: Boy, , was behind wheel of truck that caused horric crash that killed NINERicky Siemens was illegally driving a truck, with his dad in the passenger seat, when a tyre burst and they slammed head on into a van in Texas, USA Image: FacebookByKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments A -year-old boy was driving a pickup truck that smashed into a van and killed nine people, including both himself and his own father and a number of teenagers in a horror blaze in Texas, USA. Ricky Siemens was driving illegally in a truck that was on a spare tyre when the wheel burst. His truck had a head on smash into a van carrying young golfers from a Texas university, on Tuesday night. The National Transportation Safety Board vice-chair Bruce Landsberg confirmed the horric incident which led to a number of deaths, over half of whom were teenagers. They smashed into a van carrying eight University of the Southwest golf students, six of whom and their coach died.The fiery smash happened west of Dallas, Texas, just north of the towns of Midland and Odessa. Ricky had been driving with his -year-old dad Henrich Siemens, a dad-of-five, with the pair were on their way to pick up a new car at the time.  Agatha ‘Aggie’ Siemens, the widowed mum who lost her husband and son in the crash said: “They were going to pick up a car that [Siemens] bought. “I was supposed to see him about two hours later,” The New York Post reported. The crash killed college golfers Mauricio Sanchez, , Travis Garcia, , Jackson Zinn, , Karisa Raines, , Laci Stone, , and Tiago Sousa, . Two students, Hayden Underhill and Dayton Price, survived the horric smash. They were pulled from the wreckage and airlted to a nearby hospital where as of yesterday they remained in critical condition. Mr Price suffered third-degree burns to nearly half his body according to the description of a GoFundMe campaign that has since raised £,. Their coach Tyler James, , who was driving the young athletes was also tragically killed in the accident.After their tyre burst, the van swerved across the central reservation and slammed into the oncoming van head on. “This was clearly a high-speed collision,” Landsberg said, but he added it was unclear how fast the vehicles were travelling. Sergeant Steven Blanco of Texas DPS told the New York Post that the cause of the crash had not yet been determined and cops ordered toxicology and other forensic reports. According to state law in the area, motorists must be at least  years old to get their provisional licence, and at least  before they can begin to get classes to get their learner’s licence.  The college’s Ford Transit van was carrying nine people and towing a box trailer while heading back from a recent golf tournament, where both the women’s and men’s teams had competed.The accident remains under investigation and grieving relatives mourned their losses on Facebook.Ms Siemens posted a collage tribute to her two boys which read: “in loving memory” surrounded by pictures of the family. Ms Siemens posted another tribute to the boy on Facebook with a photo of her son in his NASA T-shirt and tracksuit pants, smiling at the camera. The NTSB revealed the age of the driver on Thursday but didn’t identy him.  Tributes have been pouring in for the six college golfers and coach who were killed in the crash. Gary Raines, father of Karisa, , who died in the accident, speaking on the Today show, said: “We are praying so much for the families of all those other kids. “Right now we just keep thinking we’re gonna wake up from this terrible nightmare. But itaposs not happening.” Karisa’s mum, Sandy, said: “I donapost know what Iaposm going to do without her.” A fundraiser for funeral expenses for Karisa has raised £, so far.  A memorial has been set up at the golf course where the team practiced, with flowers, gold balls and handmade signs left for the youngsters. Rockwind Community Links manager, Ben Kirkes saw the golfers almost everyday. He said: “aposWe have a memorial. Itaposs the very least we could do for the players and of course coach James. Itaposs a tough time. “These kids were great kids and they were great, great community members. They were polite and they were just a pleasure to be around.” Ryan Erwin, vice president for student engagement and athletics at East Texas Baptist University in Marshall, said that Coach James had been “living out his dream”. story: Womans hoarder house is unrecognisable after company spends hours removing trashA woman who became depressed during the coronavirus pandemic was ready for a new change, so contacted a junk removal company to help clear out her hoarder houseThe woman wanted a fresh new startByJulia BanimAudience Writer:,  Mar |comments A woman who became depressed during Covid felt ready to make a change, and so contacted a team of junk removal specialists to help clear her apos hoarder houseapos.The pandemic had a serious impact on the unnamed womanaposs mental health, leaving her sheltered inside for two years and too frightened to go out in public. Wanting to move forward, the homeowner contacted Supreme Empire Junk, a junk removal and dumpster rental company operating in Nevada, US, to help her out with the clutter that filled her house. Within the space of just three hours, the team had cleared  cubic yards of trash from the property in Henderson, using both of their dumpsters. Thanks to their hard work, this lady has been given a fresh start to a new beginning.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here.In an extremely satisfying TikTok video shared by the firm, which goes by the username @ supremeempirejunk, the team showed off their handiwork, with the home looking almost unrecognisable without the junk covering up her floors and surfaces.After just a few short hours, the house looked freshened up and much more like a home, with cleaners now preparing to come in and finish the job. As the team explained in the clip: Now that weaposre finished removing the trash, our cleaners will go inside and mop, sweep, dust, and make this place look even more beautul again!Followers have been very impressed by the result, and have wished the woman well in her now very pleasant looking home. One person commented that it is such a beautul house, adding: I hope she keeps it this way. While another remarked: Covid robbed a lot from us all during the two years! A third person urged people: Don’t judge what you don’t understand. Just hope she finds her way again. Looks like she’s been going through a rough time.Do you have a hoarding-related story to share  We pay for stories.
