It has already been reserved for the Kintyre Way relay race in June.The project has been carried out by the Kintyre Community Trust which is holding an open day tomorrow Saturday from am to pm.#There have been numerous challenges along the way, from brick suppliers who went into liquidation to the question of whether to put a pot on the fourth chimney,# said a spokesman for the trust.#This is a great project that has removed a bit of urban decay and replaced it with a new business opportunity that capitalises on what Campbeltown has to offer.#TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOThe row over school closures in Argyll and Bute is rumbling on with some councillors demanding a list of schools that could potentially be shut.Council leaders and education officials are still denying the existence of a #hit list#.At Friday#s finance and personnel meeting, the question of school closures was brought up by Councillor Sandy McQueen. He asked why the council had not issued a list of schools that would fit the criteria for closure.Kintyre councillor George McMillan said he couldn#t accept that there was legislation that could prevent a council from issuing a potential closure list.Councillor McQueen asked: #Is there not a way round this by putting forward a document with proposals that the schools may be closed #The Self-Governing Schools Act for Scotland  stops the council from being as open as it would like. The act relates to schools #opting out# from local authority control and it is feared that some schools will try to opt out to prevent closure.Council leader Dick Walsh said: #It would create real problems for some communities in Argyll and Bute and school boards would want to look at opting out.#He added: #The number of school closures depends on the budget meeting. It wouldn#t make sense at all to produce a list saying we are going to close all the schools when it might not be necessary.#FIFTY YEARS AGOThe MacBrayne#s* steamer service to Islay, Gigha, Jura and Colonsay will continue after its planned cessation date March .The news follows a public inquiry which was held at Port Ellen last month.After studying a report from the Transport Users Consultative Committee, Scots Secretary Mr Gordon Campbell has asked for the service to be continued until September .This will give him time to study the report and arrive at a long-term solution.A delighted Mrs Winnie Ewing, the former SNP MP who represented the islanders at the inquiry, said this week: #This is marvellous news. It means we have won. I visit Islay a lot and I know that to withdraw these services would mean tragedy.#And Lady Strathcona, the Colonsay landowner, commented: #We heartily applaud this decision. The Secretary of State took the wrong one last November.#The people on these islands will be very pleased to hear that he is going to consider alternatives and other methods during the summer season.#Said Mr Peter Wordie, chairman of rival group Western Ferries, which received a £, government subsidy last year: #This will not make the slightest dference to us.#We will continue to run the islands with the exception of Colonsay.#During last month#s inquiry it was claimed that Islay, Jura and Gigha would suffer hardshipthe service was withdrawn.It was also alleged that Colonsay, with its population of , would die.*Editor#s note: Caledonian MacBrayne, later CalMac did not did not come into being until  when the Caledonian Steam Packet Co acquired MacBrayne#s.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThe Clyde ringnet herring fishing vessel, Pride of the Clyde– owner skipper Mr Archibald Kerr, Tarbert – ran aground on Thursday morning just north of Skipness Point, Kintyre, in Kilbrannan Sound.The fishing boat Boy Danny of Campbeltown, radioed a message to Campbeltown and the local leboat, City of Glasgow, Coxswain Duncan Newlands in charge, proceeded to the casualty.The leboat reached the fishing boat shortly after am.The coxswain and crew managed to get a rope aboard the boat and pulled her off the beach.There was no damage and the fishing boat was able to make Tarbert Loch Fyne under her own power.While she was aground, the Tarbert boat Silvercrest stood by.The Pride of the Clyde was not fishing at the time. She had been out with the fleet, but had dficulty with her nets, so she was ing home from Ballantrae to get another net when she grounded in the heavy morning fog.Mr Kerr later stated that there was a sair wind and visibility was poor.He asks us to thank all who in anyway assisted or rendered aid to him and his crew that morning and so helped in the safety of the boat.The thick fog persisted throughout Friday, interrupting shipping and air services.The BEA plane services to Campbeltown were cancelled and all flying training at the Royal Naval Air Station was suspended for the same reason.

title: leader march 11 2022
story: One of the five tenets of taekwon-do is indomitable spirit.That is something which has been displayed in abundance in the last two weeks, since Russian forces invaded Ukraine.Despite all they are currently facing, Ukrainian soldiers took time on Tuesday, on International Women#s Day, to hand flowers to women they stopped at checkpoints.Viral videos of off-duty Ukrainian soldiers dancing in their unorms continue to flood social media.And, amid leading the fight against Russian invaders and holding meetings with world leaders, the country#s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, welcomed the start of spring in an outdoors video, ending the broadcast with a wink to the camera.The strength of spirit Ukrainians continue to show, from the bottom to the very top, should be an inspiration to us all.Kintyre has already shown incredible community spirit in its response to the crisis – well done to every person who contributed.And, although it might not effect change on a global scale, SG Taekwon-Do#s display of support for Ukraine shows that there are people in every corner of the world willing to stand up for democracy and what they believe is right.

title: letters march 11 2022
story: The Campbeltown Courier printed a story in February  about a painting, Village in the Valley, by H Shapiro.A reader then wrote to you, letting you know that the painting was by Hyman Shapiro and informed you that he had three children.I am one of Hyman Shapiro#s granddaughters. He had five children, not three.Before he was married to Gretl, the potter mentioned in the reader#s letter, he had two daughters, Gladys and Ruth, by his first we, Margaret, who died of tuberculosis.My mother Ruth, like her father, is a talented artist who has exhibited paintings.My we had to call the emergency services for me last Friday night at .am and,  minutes later, an ambulance arrived and the two paramedics provided me with great care and attention before transporting me to Campbeltown Hospital.I would like to thank them for the care and attention given to me.They do not receive as much gratitude from the public as they should and I would like to put on record my heartfelt thanks for their dedication and help in a very stressful period.Do the people of Campbeltown and her surrounding South Kintyre communities truly believe local frustrations are being heard in Kilmory Or have our three sitting councillors been napping this past decade, resting on their laurels, in the belief they are unaccountable to voters.It has been  years since the people of South Kintyre have voted in a local election. If you want to continue having the same conversations, raising the same issues, exasperated with the same results, thenthe same trio at the polls on May  and expect the same for the next five years.As a young man, I made a commitment to serve my country as a Royal Marines Commando now, I am prepared to make that same commitment to my community.I promise to proudly serve the people of South Kintyre to the best of my ability and present a strong new Conservative Unionist voice.If we do not meet on the doorstep in the coming months, can I encourage you to make your mark, on May , for a positive change to South Kintyre#s immediate future.I write after thousands of pounds worth of educational books were thrown in the bin in Oban.It is essential that our council#s leadership makes sure that hard-pressed council taxpayers are being provided with value for money. This in my opinion is a prime example of a failure to do so.The council leader talks a great deal about environmentalism but how is this environmental This is particularly saddening given the fact that so many teachers often struggle for ample educational booklets.My constituents are asking why our council taxes are having to go up when mountains of perfectly good books are being thrown in the skip It is beyond belief that this can be allowed to happen. These expensive books could be put to much better use than this.

title: pupils u17s return to kintyre with well earned point
story: Campbeltown Pupils YFC sed to Kintyre on Sunday night happy with a point after an eventful Glasgow and District Youth Football League encounter against Rutherglen Glencairn.Played at the Toryglen Regional Centre in basking sunshine more akin to a summer’s day, the young Pupils team got off to a poor start and found themselves - down after five minutes.The visitors really struggled to get to grips with the game in the opening  minutes but eventually found some rhythm and started to control the game.After  minutes, Stuart Phillips equalised with a cracking right foot finish into the top hand corner from  yards out.With five minutes of the half remaining, Calum Ellis made it - to the Pupils with a well-executed goal.As the first half drew to a close there looked to be only one winner, with the Pupils dominating the game.As in the first half, the Pupils started the second half slowly and it was the Glasgow side who dominated and made it - in the nd minute with a cracking goal.The Pupils, uncharacteristically, lost their way and Rutherglen made it - in the st minute from the penalty spot.Six minutes later, it easily could have been - but for heroic defending and goalkeeping from Ryan Harding and Lorne Paterson.With  minutes left, things went from bad to worse as Graham saw red for his second yellow card of the game and the Ardshiel Hotel-sponsored side were reduced to  men and trailing by a goal.A switch was badly needed and Scott Oman was introduced in goal with the Pupils going to a back three of Kyle Paterson, Josh Arkell and Euan Dott, with Lorne Paterson moving from goal into the centre of midfield with Kyle Danson.Ironically, the Pupils started to play their best football of the half and deservedly equalised with  minutes remaining.A penalty was awarded and Ellis made no mistake from  yards to make it -.With five minutes remaining, Ryan Shields had a great opportunity to take the lead but there was no more scoring and the Pupils should be happy with their point.This Sunday , the s host St Patrick#s in league business with a midday kick-off on the G AWP, Kinloch Green.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022
story: Who am I  What am I  Where am I  How am I  – questions of identity and some of the questions I was left asking when I left a recent meeting.That meeting was part of a world-wide movement – a movement that calls the peoples of the world to pray.Similar questions of identity were raised when I was asked to write ‘a piece’ for this newspaper. The questions weren’t so much about me but you – who are you  What are you  Where are you  And how are you I can answer the questions about ‘me’ relatively easily, knowing that others might disagree. But I cannot so easily answer such questions about you for I don’t really know who reads this column.Identity, human identity, all of us wrestle with questions of identity – from the inidual to a community to a nation or a race.Who are the Scots  Who are the Ukrainians  Who are the Russians  Where do you come from The answers are never as simple as we think they might be or would like them to be.Humanity is such a erse and multi-faceted part of creation.In recent weeks, many have tried to understand why the world finds itself on the potential tipping point of another large-scale war.In part, it is to do with identity – a simplication, I know – and a greed for power, land and wealth.Doomsters will shake their heads and wring their hands in despair, offering little hope.Politicians will talk and negotiate and may God bless them as they do!What will you do Your response will reflect something of your identity.Will you identy with a world-wide movement and pray for the well-being of the world

title: mica gets the chop for charities
story: The Dalintober Primary School pupil is donating her cut hair to the Little Princess Trust, to help make wigs for children and young people affected by hair loss, and she is donating money raised through sponsorship to Comic Relief.In , Mica#s family moved to Campbeltown from Peru, where it#s common for girls to have very long hair.#Mica has wanted her hair cut for ages, for maybe three years, since before she came to Scotland,# explained her mum Elizabeth. #She is very sporty and, so, a shorter haircut is much easier for her to manage.#She didn’t want her hair to go to waste and thought maybe it could benefit other children who have illnesses that make their hair fall out or those having cancer treatment.#Mica also decided to raise money for charity and chose Comic Relief because funds raised are spent helping poor and disadvantaged people both in the UK and in the world’s poorest communities.Gayle Durnin at Gloss Hair did the honours on Tuesday, March , turning Mica#s long do into a sleek bob. She very kindly did not charge for the haircut as a donation to the cause.The last time Mica had short hair was when she was an infant but despite the big change, she is very pleased with her decision.#She wasn#t scared, only happy,# Elizabeth said. #She has only ever had her hair slightly trimmed in her letime and it was probably at its longest during lockdown. She is very excited about the change of look.#Elizabeth added: #Mica wanted her hair cut and her dad and I are extremely proud that she wasn#t just thinking entirely about herself but thought about how she could use her haircut as an opportunity to help benefit other children.#The money she is raising for Comic Relief will help so many disadvantaged children in this country, abroad and, of course, in Ukraine.#We think how grateful we are to be able to live in a peaceful country, while, for many, simple activities like getting a haircut are secondary to basic survival.#Mica has already smashed her initial fundraising target of £, raising an incredible £ on her JustGiving page, but she would welcome any additional donations.Visit justgiving fundraising elizabeth-nimmo-de-amaut to donate.#Thank you to everyone who has donated so far,# said Elizabeth, #Mica really never expected to raise so much just from a haircut.#

title: wrestler iona sky takes down london lovelust
story: The Tarbert Academy pupil won despite interference from LoveLust#s manager, but at what cost Afterwards, the punk rock princess donned a plaid shirt and moved to the dark side of the company, joining the nefarious Struthers Sisters and beatdown LoveLust.At the end of the show, the Struthers faction, including Sky, were kept from entering the ring and it looks like wrestling fans could be in for a power struggle between the House Of LoveLust and The Struthers Family in Renegade Wrestling – dangerous times!Sky did all this the day after she and fellow Tarbert Academy pupil Guthrie Scott supported music sensations Peat and Diesel at their sold-out Tarbert show on Friday night with their band Anavrin.

title: bowlers at twos and threes in the clubhouse
story: Members have been warming up for the outdoor season with a iety of carpet bowls competitions in the comfort of their own clubhouse.On February  the first winter competition was held for the Archie Morans Triples Cup and this was won by Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard.On Saturday the final of the Gilchrist Joiners sponsored Open Pairs was contested and after a competitive three nights two father-and-son pairings progressed to vie for the title.The pairings of Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.The final was closely contested with Jimmy and Craig coming out winners.Organisers congratulated Jimmy and Craig who proved worthy winners and thanked everyone who took part over the week along with new sponsor Gilchrist Joiners.Pic caps: Angus Brodie Jnr and Snr and Jimmy and Craig Anderson landed in the final after beating Robert Coffield and Ryan McLachlan and David Brown and George Allen respectively.Angus Brodie Jnr, Angus Brodie Snr and Keith Sheppard lted the Archie Morans Triples Cup.

title: photograph of the week march 11 2022 2
story: Since the beginning of lockdown Jane has been going out and about with her Galaxy Tablet collecting scenic shots from all over the island. What#s more there are no filters or any tampering whatsoever in her photographs.Just the natural beauty of the West Coast.

title: dogged display on the dunaverty course
story: In the first group out Katharine Hardman played a steady game, despite an unaccompanied dog joining the group on the th green and temporarily pinching her ball.Even with the best endeavours of the dog to disrupt the next couple of holes and increasing wind, Katharine carded a respectable and took the lead.The second group also had to contend with the dog for a couple of holes but this did not deter Eleanor Hawkins who also matched Katharine#s score, but as she had a better inward half took first place.Result: , Eleanor Hawkins #  , Katharine Hardman # , Katie Cappello # .

title: climate change call
story: Stan Phillips gave the stark warning to community chiefs after the International Panel on Climate Changepublished a report saying climate change was worse than predicted.Mr Phillips is chairman of a short le working group set up by Argyll and Bute Community Planning Partnership , which held a virtual meeting on Wednesday  March .Alok Sharma, the UK president of the UN climate talks, was among those who urged faster action when the report was published.Mr Phillips, who works for NatureScot and lives in Lochgilphead, now hopes to find funding to invest in a project officer post.He told the meeting: #On February , a report came out stating that in terms of climate change, things are way worse than we thought.#I was pretty sure that report would have occupied headlines over the past couple of weeks, but because of the conflict in Ukraine, it has not had much of a look-in.#So the message is we need to go much further and faster on climate change action. We have spent the last couple of months working with other parties to see how they work.#It is clear we need to employ at least one person as project officer to work up plans for climate change engagement in Argyll and Bute.#We assume it costs £, to set up one post for one year, and that is a lot of money to find, so we have started looking for funds already.#Mr Phillips added: #This affects the council, its roads and infrastructure and will affect health and welfare, due to many issues, not least fuel price rises.#Every group in Argyll and Bute is going to have to consider how they will transform themselves into a carbon neutral business.#It is a task for all of us and I am formally asking us all to go and find finance to take this project forward. I said it was coming and this is the day.#Joe McKay, chairman of the CPP, who works for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, replied: #I can help you out with some fundingwe speak off the table.#I am not promising a large amount but I can help you outwe were quick. There is also a plan in place for electric charging points at all of my stations.#

title: from our files friday march 18
story: Friday March  Gigha was alive yesterday, Thursday, as people travelled to join in the celebrations for its th anniversary of community ownership.Campbeltown Junior Pipe Band piped the children from the local primary school down the main road to the hotel to emphasise the change in the number of children on the island.The children donned their new unorms to mark the occasion, carrying the Gigha flag.Fundraising has been ongoing over a period of time to raise cash towards the celebrations.To date more than £, has been raised, and events have included a race night, celebrations at New Year, and a quiz night.Last night islanders gathered for the ceilidh to bring the celebrations to a close.TWENTY FIVE YEARS AGOFriday March  Argyll’s newest nursing home was officially opened in Campbeltown.The £, Kintyre Nursing Home, which is situated in Hall Street overlooking Campbeltown Loch, was formally opened by Councillor George McMillan.Speaking during the opening of the new home, Mr McMillan said thatthe care in the home was as good as the building itself, no one would have anything to worry about.He went on to explain that getting the home build have not always been an easy task.‘There were some dficulties about the site because of the ground conditions but there were also other problems with the planners about this site because it’s a very prominent site and it’s next door to some very fine buildings on the left-hand side.‘It was a problem getting the plan is to agree to the ious shapes and types of materials that were to be used, but we overcame all these things and got the go-ahead.’FIFTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Popular local turf accountant, Mr Hugh McKellar, has won a holiday for two in Majorca in a raffle organised by Tarbert Football Club.Mr McKellar did not even know he had won the prize. For he threw away the tickets he had bought, thinking that the dance at which the winning ticket was to be drawn had been held.But, unbeknown to him, the fuel crisis meant that thewas postponed for a week.When told he had won the prize, Mr McKellar was flabbergasted.‘It was the biggest surprise of my le. And I’ve had a few,’ he told a Courier man later.Mr McKellar and his we, Christine, both bought tickets. They are still arguing over who won the prize!Mr and Mrs McKellar live with their family at  Ralston Road Campbeltown.SEVENTY YEARS AGOThursday March  Refloated by Campbeltown LeboatAfter the tow-rope had parted in one attempt, the crew of the Campbeltown leboat, City of Glasgow were lucky in the third venture, when, on a two-and-a-half hour ebb tide, they pulled off the  tons Glasgow coaster Saint Kentigern, which had run aground, bow on, on a ledge of rock on the notorious Paterson’s reef, off the island of Sanda, Mull of Kintyre, in dense fog, on Monday night.The leboat put to see at : pm in response to news from Mr John Macintyre, Lady Mary Row, a member of the leboat crew, who, listening on the short wave, picked up a radio message from the distressed coaster that she was in dficulties and required leboat assistance.The fog had come down suddenly in the late evening and conditions were very thick when the leboat nosed out of Campbeltown Loch and around Davaar.There was a slight breeze and the sea was almost comparatively calm.Standing by, just over six cables away from the coaster, was the Ardchattan of  tons, also belonging to Mrs J and a Gardner and Company,  Clyde Street, Glasgow.Near at hand was the Burns-Laird cargo steamer, Lairdsdale, which had erted course while en-route to Londonderry, to stand-by. Also standing by was the steamer Brora, which was bund for Belfast.The conditions were so bad from the point of view of visibility that the leboat had to receive bearings from the Brora and other ships by means of the Aldis signal lamps while ships’ searchlights assisted them in getting into position. For a time the ships could only see each other on the radar screen.Coxswain Duncan Newlands, who knows this dreaded part of the estuary like the back of his hand, edged his leboat in astern of the coaster and proceeded to begin operations, but at .am came this dramatic message over the leboat’s radio: ‘Arrived alongside casualty at .hours got rope aboard and commenced towing at . hours.‘Rope now parted. Returning alongside St Kentigern for further instructions.’There was a lull in the activities while the leboat resumed its operations. They tried again- without success.Then came the news at . hours – ‘St Kentigern Refloated.’The leboat has succeeded in its third attempt, against odds.The St Kentigern then proceeded to Campbeltown under her own power, while the leboat escorted her, but first it took in tow the coaster’s own leboat, which it had earlier lowered over the port side in case of an emergency.The Ardchattern also accompanied the Saint Kentigern to Campbeltown.Meantime, the two remaining ships, Lairdsdale and Brora, seeing their attendance was no longer required, sent a parting signal of good-luck to the coaster and continued on their respective passages to towards the Irish Coast.

title: information is key in kintyre
story: Campbeltown-based Keeping it local CICis introducing the screens up and down the peninsula, including Tarbert and on the Isle of Gigha.A spokesperson for the community interest company said: #With the support of fantastic businesses all over we are able to provide up-to-date information on events, news, travel and destination areas to visit all around the area at the touch of a button.#The work we do is also supported by advertising on our screens while promoting your own business offerings.#The boards should be up and running by April, all being well.The aim of Keeping it local CIC is to support businesses, trades, services and events by collating information and bringing all that Kintyre has to offer under one roof # a one-stop-shop for the consumer and businesses.The Tarbert information boards are due to be located at One Fyne Deli and at The Gather restaurant.

title: island residents and friends have a happy 20th gigha day
story: Celebrations were in full swing this week as residents on the Isle of Gigha marked  years of community ownership.After extensive community fundraising alongside securing grants and loans from Highlands and Islands Enterprise and the National Lottery, Gigha was purchased by the community for the sum of £m on March  .On this day the island was handed over to the Isle of Gigha Heritage Trusta day that is marked on the island every year as #Gigha Day#.To commemorate this -year milestone all Gigha residents and key island stakeholders were invited to watch Gigha’s eldest female resident Ina McNeill raise the island flag on Tuesday.This was followed by a display from the pupils of Gigha Primary School and a performance by the Kintyre Schools Pipe Band, who made the journey over from Campbeltown to attend.The Isle of Gigha Hotel then welcomed the guests for refreshments and to view a display of island memorabilia and photographs from the past  years.Since the buyout the permanent population of the island has grown from around  up to  residents.This has been achieved through housing renovations and new affordable housing, coupled with increased economic development.Gigha has several businesses which support employment on the island and IGHT now employs  people across its office, maintenance team, Achamore Gardens, new campsite, marketing, and ranger service.This includes two apprentices who are contributing to the restoration of Achamore Gardens.The trust is managed by a board of voluntary directors who are elected by the membership to develop the assets of the island and take forward plans and projects for the community.IGHT  retains ownership of the majority of the built and land assets of the island, worth over £m.Since the buy-out in  IGHT has renovated  houses as part of an ongoing investment programme, sold  plots for private self-build development, developed four wind turbines which help fund development, installed moorings and pontoon facilities, successfully marketed Gigha’s tourism assets as well as working to protect and conserve Gigha’s heritage and environment.One of the trust’s biggest challenges has been managing its financial position.The trust’s debt levels increased to £.m in  after taking out loans to deliver housing renovations.This debt burden is now reduced to £,, which has been achieved through asset sales and income from its renewable and trading companies.The trust has a number of projects underway including a new campsite, km of new and upgraded path networks, on-site and online heritage interpretation, five new housing units, and a -year restoration plan for Achamore Gardens.The trust is actively trying to reduce the island#s carbon footprint through  e-bikes for hire from the activity centre and is also soon to install the island#s first electric vehicle charging point.

title: leader march 11 2022 2
story: So the Scottish Government remains adamant in its decision to ban creelers from the Clyde for the next two months or so.We#re not talking North Sea trawlers here that can go where in the interim. We#re talking about small family businesses whose livelihoods depend on them setting their creels in the Clyde.Many have invested heavily in their boats and equipment and have no other options available to them but to sit it out.Many employees of Dawnfresh Seafoods were brought to their knees recently after being denied a week#s wages. Our creel fishermen are having to survive  weeks.Financial compensation is a must and government ministers should now make it a priority to offer this. Before irreversible harm is done.Much has already been said about the rallying of our community to come to the aid of the people fleeing their homes in war-torn Ukraine.But we will keep on saying it.This week it was the efforts from our youngest inhabitants that shone through. From collecting donations to making, drawing and writing messages of hope to their European peers.Keep up the good work, everyone.

title: letters march 11 2022 2
story: With some fishermen enduring three weeks of no income and a further eight weeks until the current ban on fishing in the Clyde Recovery Box comes to an end, it was fantastic to see that Argyll and Bute MSP Jenni Minto has lobbied the Minister for Rural Affairs Mairi Gougeon to get financial assistance to help the fishers through this dficult time.Not surprisingly, the Scottish Government have still refused any assistance.At a meeting of the Rural Affairs, Island and Natural Environment Committee on Wednesday March  a vote was taken on whether to annul the ban on fishing in the recovery box.Sadly the MSP for Argyll and Bute decided to look after her own pay packet, political career and tow the line with her Nationalist colleagues to support the ban on fishing in the area.This caused fellow committee member Scottish Conservative Rachel Hamilton to suggest backbenchers, with reference to Ms Minto, are #spineless#.Having deserted the local fishermen, their families and supporting businesses Ms Minto has shown yet another example of Nationalist MSPs being afraid to rock the boat in Holyrood.The Scottish Government has banned creel fishing in parts of the Clyde as part of a plan to protect cod.It was pointed out to our MSP Jenny Minto that:.    The bodies campaigning for this ban did NOT want or need creel fishermen included for the protection of baby cod..    The scientic advice was modied to exclude creel fishing. Baby young cod are not caught in prawn creels. The scientists at the Rural Affairs Committee meeting on March  said that there was zero evidence for creels to be included in the ban, and that the previous evidence cited on the Scottish Government website had now been removed.Our MSP represented to the creel fishermen in Campbeltown that she would:.    Seek a relaxation of the ban to enable the creel fishermen to continue to work as per the scientic evidence advice..    Seek compensation for the creel fishermen for almost three months loss of income.However, in the event she VOTED.    To keep the ban in place.    Against compensation.This is absolutely duplicitous. Duplicity#s original meaning in English has to do with a kind of deception in which true feelings or intentions are hidden behind  words or actions.I wouldn’t blame the children of South Sudanthey just gave up.One third are suffering chronic malnutrition. Half are missing school. Millions are displaced. And none of them have ever known anything but war.One of my colleagues there, a -year-old man, tells me he has never seen peace in his letime. But he has seen hope. He has witnessed the hope our colourful bowls full of maize and beans bring to some of the poorest children on earth.Mary’s Meals feeds more than two million children every school day in  of the world’s poorest countries.Our nutritious meals attract little ones into the classroom, where they can gain an education that gives them hope for the future.We are already reaching around , hungry children in South Sudan, and – with the support of your readers – we can serve our le-changing meals in even more schools. Please visit marysmeals.org.uk to find out more about our appeal.The children of South Sudan aren’t giving up. And nor are we. We know that no child on this earth is unreachable.

title: rest campaign seeks uk government help 2
story: That was the message delivered to Iain Stewart, UK Government Minister in Scotland, at a high-powered meeting last week to discuss the Rest and be Thankful.Convened by John Gurr, chair of business-led Rest and be Thankful Campaign, the gathering in the George Hotel included Argyll and Bute chief executive Pippa Milne, council leader Robin Currie, constituency MSP Jenni Minto, regional MSPs Rhoda Grant and Donald Cameron and Brendan O#Hara MP.Among the business representatives were Kenny MacLeod, director of MacLeod Construction Ltd, Duncan McAllister of NFU Scotland, Jane MacLeod of Mid Argyll Chamber of Commerce, Iain Catterwell representing timber haulage, Donna Irwin of Loch Fyne Oysters and Argyll Estates factor Hugh Nicol.Fteen years of disruption on the A at the Rest and be Thankful culminated in two major landslides in August and September .In total the A carriageway at the Rest was closed for  days that year, with a -plus mile detour in place for more than a month.The estimated economic cost to Argyll and Bute in the eight months between August ,  and March ,  was £. million.The road#s unreliability, the minister heard, is a factor in population decline impacts the area#s ability to fund services and hampers Argyll#s ability to attract a workforce and keep local businesses viable.Mr Gurr said: #The A at the Rest has not been fully open without traffic lights since , and traffic continues to be moved to the old military road detour, under traffic lights and convoy, when it rains.#When you drive past at mph, you#re thinking #will I get hit by a landslide#. It#s scary.#In  Transport Scotland selected the #cheapest# option from a  report by Jacobs Engineering. Nine years and £ million later they are still digging.#The Scottish Government has committed to building a #permanent solution# at the Rest, expected to take up to  years to complete. What is not clear is what solution it will adopt and when work will start.While transport is a devolved matter, the meeting on March  was intended to raise awareness within the Scotland Office of the importance of Argyll, and the A, to the UK # and explore any support it could give to speeding up the process.In  the UK Government published a Union Connectivity Report # with Argyll conspicuous by its absence. Mr Stewart was asked whether the region could be added to the list of transport priorities.The minister replied that while #there is no magic wand# he agreed that it was an emergency involving a leline road.He said: #I will be speaking with Scottish Transport Secretary Jenny Gilruth soon. The Rest and be Thankful, and the calls for urgency on the A, will be high on our agenda.#Meanwhile, the UK Government will be looking at whether our Union Connectivity Review, Levelling Up Fund and Shared Prosperity Fund have potential for the Rest and be Thankful.#

title: schools animation event rescheduled due to covid
story: Due to take place at Campbeltown Picture House todaythe event will now take place on Friday, April .Glenbarr and Clachan#s films and awards will start at am. Those wishing to attend are asked to telephone Glenbarr on   or Clachan on   to reserve a place, as it is important to keep track of numbers.Rhunahaorine#s showcase will begin at .pm. To attend the afternoon event, call Rhunahaorine on  .This has all been made possible with a grant from the West Kintyre Windfarm Trust, for which all involved are extremely grateful.

title: thought for the week march 11 2022 2
story: As our planet continues its journey around the sun we notice that theIt is not so dark in the morning and the daylight is extending in the evening. In other words, we are leaving winter behind and spring is around the corner.Although winter brings dark days it also has wonderful surprises on clear nights when the stars seem to dance in the sky and with planets making appearances from time to time.However we must focus on spring. That is where we are just now. This isTrusting from previous years we plant seeds in the knowledge that they will probably germinate and grow into plants before too long. It’s all an amazing process as new le forms.Are the churches still living in dark days or are there signs of new le  Alas in so many places it looks like the former with declining membership rolls and constant struggles to keep going. Given the right conditions however, growth is virtually unstoppable. We see that from the way the grass grows week after week.So what are the churches doing to prevent growth  Are they ploughing the same furrow over and over again or are they looking for fresh ways to cultivate interest It’s not easy butwe resist change it’s going to become even harder.Springtime invites us to take a fresh look at things and sharpen up our prospects for the future. We shouldn’t be afraid to look at things afresh.That’s when we discover new ideas. New ideas bring new le. Let’s be positive about the future.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as “a real dream come true”.She said: “We are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.”Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk – The Cheese Lady – has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: “We needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.“We want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.“Also, I’m hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.”Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: “Whoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That’s fantastic.“And it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.”Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: “I think we are in a good place.“When we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!”

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than £,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: “We are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.“Mary has raised a fantastic £, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.”Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised £, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman’s Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: “This year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.“I’m walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!”People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: line-duty-watch-exclusive-ac-12-reunion
story: Martin Compston, Vicky McClure and Adrian Dunbar are reuniting with the writer of the show Jed Mercurio for a "one-off" reunion event in aid of Ardgowan Hospice, where Martin is a patron.The trio, who have been nicking "bent coppers" on screen for a decade, will get together on March  in Port Glasgow Town Hall, close to Martins home in Greenock.All proceeds from the live event will help the local hospice continue its le-changing work in the community.----------------------------The exclusive video will only be available to our subscribers.You can pay as little as £ for your first month and that fee will go directly to Martins favourite charity, Ardgowan Hospice.To sign up, visit our subscribe page here and take advantage of our latest amazing offers.Our exclusive recording of the event will be available to subscribers HERE from Thursday March .For those who already subscribe, you will also receive exclusive access to the video.Subscriptions can be cancelled at any time.If you would like to make a further donation to Ardgowan Hospice, you can do so HERE.

title: flora-gentlemans-grandparents-ready-peppa-pig-walk
story: Flora Gentleman, three, is approaching the final six months of NHS treatment for her stage four neuroblastoma cancer.In January last year, Flora was diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder and just three months later her parents were given the devastating news she had high-risk neuroblastoma.The youngster’s family are appealing to raise £, by August for Flora to enrol on the bivalent vaccine clinical trial in New York that aims to stop her neuroblastoma from coming back.Now, her grandparents Margaret and Robert Kent, from Dirleton, will pull on their walking books to hike km, starting in Helensburgh on April  and finishing in Dunbar on May .Flora GentlemanFlora’s granny, a psychotherapist, recently contributed to £, raised in December with her Santa’s Grotto Christmas fundraiser, which saw her transform her garage and garden into a winter wonderland for the children of East Lothian.Meanwhile, Robert, a business consultant, will join her as the pair dress as Granny and Grandpa Pig from the toddler’s favourite television show.Stephanie Kent, Flora’s mum, is asking county residents to stop, wave and even sing the Peppa Pig theme song should they see the couple on their fundraising walk.Stephanie is also hoping that businesses in the area will get involved and support the cause.She said: “We need all the support we can get at this point to get Flora on a plane to New York in August.“We’d love for people to join us in welcoming Granny and Grandpa Pig back to East Lothian turf on May  in Dunbar.Floras grandparents will take on an epic challenge later this year “We will let people know what time they will arrive so we can give them a warm reception.”At present, Flora’s family have raised more than £, of £, which will allow the youngster to travel to America for treatment.To donate to Granny and Grandpa Pig’s sponsored walk, visit solvingkidscancer.org.uk fundraisers granny-grandpa-pig-take-on-john-muir-wayTo donate by text, send ‘FLORA’ followed by any whole amount up to £ to .

title: youngsters-plant-wee-forest-queen-margaret-university
story: The youngsters from Stoneyhill and Musselburgh Burgh Primary Schools joined students and academics to create a tennis court-sized area with dense planting of fast-growing native woodland – the first part of a bigger plan to create an outdoor learning hub on campus.The hub will provide access to dferent environments for learning activity, wellbeing, community engagement and professional development. It will become a central point of learning for students, the local community and wider teaching profession.Pupils from Stoneyhill Primary School in Musselburgh help plant some trees to create the Wee Forest in the grounds of the Queen Margaret University campus The two-day tree planting enterprise at the university is part of a £, Scottish Government funded project, led by NatureScot, which will see schools and local communities establishing  Wee Forests across the country in a bid to help tackle the climate emergency and contribute to Scotland’s tree planting targets.At QMU, crab apple, birch, blackthorn, broom, cherry, dog rose, elder, hawthorn, hazel, oak, pine, rowan and willow specimens were planted.Patrick Boxall, lecturer in initial teacher education, who is leading development of the outdoor learning hub, said: “We are starting off the way we want to continue – by involving the local community in a learning project that grounds people in nature.“It’s the perfect opportunity for school children to get their hands dirty, get involved outdoors and learn about how to plant a Wee Forest. It’s something tangible that everyone can connect with, take some ownership of the space and create a positive association with the university and the development of the hub.Ella Nicol, a P pupil at Stoneyhill Primary School in Musselburgh puts in some spadework to help create East Lothians first Wee Forest at Queen Margaret University “Throughout the pandemic, we have seen how we all benefit mentally and physically by connecting with nature, so getting people involved in the creation of the first Wee Forest in East Lothian can only be a good thing.”Mr Boxall added: “In March, the creation of a trail and shelter will begin, and we have ideas for a sensory garden, art, storytelling, performances and spaces which will support health and wellbeing, so it’s exciting to see the hub starting to take shape.”Meanwhile, in a separate initiative, a tree was also planted in the university grounds to celebrate the platinum jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II.Sir Paul Grice, the university’s principal and vice-chancellor, carried out the spadework as part of the Queen’s Green Canopy , a Woodland Trust initiative.Everyone across the UK was invited to plant a tree to mark the jubilee throughout the October  to March  tree planting season.The tree is one of many located on campus and joins several others that have been planted in honour of friends of the university.

title: bridges-project-young-mum-thanks-charity
story: Abbie Renton, , was just  years old, pregnant and “hated meeting new people” when she was referred to the youth work organisation on the town’s Bogpark Road.Five years later, she has overcome homelessness, is a soon-to-be mother of three and is more “social and happy” than ever.As she is awaiting the arrival of her baby girl, Abbie reminisced about her time with the Bridges Project, a charity to which she dedicates her success.She said: “I was introduced to Bridges Project by my family support worker at the time to help me become more confident, to make friends, to say what’s on my mind and to understand that people care.”She was referred to the charity’s personal development service, funded by BBC Children in Need, and started working with personal development worker Chris Nicol.“I soon realised Chris was someone I could talk to and he would actually listen and wasn’t just another person to judge me. Chris made me see that people do help. We spoke about things I had never told anyone,” she said.Chris helped Abbie, who is originally from Edinburgh and is a former pupil of Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans, to build her confidence and become more confident at leaving her house.Abbie also received support from other Bridges Project services to come to terms with past experiences, manage her finances and fill out ious applications.As well as this, she participated in one of the charity’s mother and baby groups.Shortly after Abbie’s first son, Coby, was born, she became homeless. However, with help from Bridges Project and her social worker, she was soon able to obtain her own home.In late , Abbie was , had a one-and-a-half-year-old son and had never felt happier.She felt she had progressed so much that she did not need support from Bridges Project anymore.“At that point, I was doing so well on my own,” she said.“That gave me a feeling like I had achieved so much from where I started.”She soon met her new partner and had another baby, Riley, who was born in February .“I am still with my partner and we are as happy as ever,” said Abbie. “We are now waiting on the arrival of our second child together – a girl who will join us in March.”She has also become close friends with other mothers from the school her oldest son attends and meets them for coffee at least once a week. She said she would not have achieved thisit was not for Bridges Project.“I still think of how far I have come to achieve this le,” added Abbie. “Bridges Project have helped me become the person I am today and have helped me become more confident. I have Bridges Project to thank for it all.”

title: funding-announced-new-path-drem-gullane
story: Discussions have been ongoing for more than a decade for a pedestrian and cyclist-friendly route connecting the two villages.Currently, anyone wanting to walk or cycle between Drem and Gullane has to use the busy B.Now, councillors have agreed to set aside £, in next year’s budget, which comes into force next month, to develop the project.Campaigners persuaded political leaders to include the funding in their spending plans to keep cyclists and pedestrians safe.At the beginning of the year, Sustrans Scotland awarded East Lothian Council £, to examine design options for the first section of the path near Drem Railway Station.Iain Monk, spokesperson for the Drem-Gullane Path Campaign, was delighted with the announcement.He said: “This is hugely important as it signies serious intent on the council’s part.“This, along with the recent £, Sustrans Scotland grant for design work, gives real opportunity for progress to be made on the path in the coming year.“Investing in active travel infrastructure is vital to keep pedestrians and cyclists safe and to encourage healthier and greener journeys.”

title: musical-programme-county-church-released
story: The Garleton Singers hold their spring concert at .pm on Sunday.For more information on the programme and tickets, go to garletonsingers.Six days later, the Hadley Court Singers perform at .pm.Their programme includes Dvorak, Brahms, Glinka and Faure.For ticket information, see hadleycourtsingers.Finally, on March , Westbourne House School Choir, from Chichester, visit.The concert is free of charge and starts at .pm, with doors opening half an hour earlier.Dalkeith  Monktonhall Brass Band also perform on May .

title: letter-week-not-right-place-youth-hub
story: To be clear, we support the creation of facilities for young people – it would prevent misuse of the woods.DCWG committee members met Cllr Hampshire in January to voice opposition to the location. He agreed to a further meeting with the directors of Dunbar Community Development and Heritage Trustin February. Cllr Hampshire has not responded to email requests.Cllr Hampshire states “the woodland area is in pretty poor condition and there has never been any management take place”. DCWG has never had any role or responsibility for that part of Lochend Wood. It is in the privately owned  hectares at Hallhill West and North. DCWG have successfully managed a separate  hectares of Lochend Wood since .As Cllr Hampshire describes, drainage ditches have collapsed at his proposed site. It is now waterlogged, not suitable for construction.An environmental impact assessment is essential. His proposed site is wild land, habitat to wildle – deer, foxes, possibly badgers, many bird species, some rare, and bats too.Lochend Wood will soon be completely surrounded by built environment.Development would be catastrophic for wildle, already suffering from signicant habitat loss and stress. Cllr Hampshire acknowledges “there is still wildle in the woodland and we will do everything we can to make sure we protect that”.Clearly, the best way to protect this area for wildle, including nocturnal species, is to NOT fill it with floodlights and noisy, boisterous humans.He continues: “People complain about young people hanging around and doing things they should not be doing.”Yet this proposal aims to attract kids to a location that is isolated and not overseen. This is dangerous. Emergency services have been called to deal with gatherings in the woods in recent times – ambulances for vulnerable young adolescents suffering serious alcohol effects, fire services, and police to disperse large groups. This location would create a perfect storm of risk.His vision – a ‘community cafe’, open  till  – would cost tens of thousands of pounds to install basic services to the site. How could this be sustainable  Even the Bleachingfield Centre cafe, with the library on site, close to the town centre and the primary school, was not viable. He suggests young people could watch television at the hub. Why not Bleachingfield or the Hallhill Centre  Why waste precious resources Great new facilities – The Space at DunBear Park – are planned. McDonald’s is already a hub for young people and it’s near bus stops. It would be perfect to locate the youth hub adjacent to The Space, somewhere kids can have some freedom, not under close adult scrutiny, yet where they could still access help from adults at Asdaneeded. Dunbar Community Woodland Group are completely against this proposed development.Eva Hurley , Fiona MacDonald , Isobel Knox , Angela McLeman, Libi Newell, Ute Penny and all the committee of Dunbar Community Woodland Group

title: north-berwick-post-boxes-get-new-spring-themed-toppers
story: The toppers made by Linda Digney and Judy Lockhart-Hunter, with help from North Berwick in Bloom, are on Quality Street and St. Baldred’s Road with one featuring a mouse and the other a bunny.Both toppers have also welcomed the addition of Pat Christie’s knitted Ukrainian hearts as the town continues to show its support for the country.The pair also made similar toppers with a festive theme at Christmas but both were stolen, with only one turning up again.However, Linda and Judy hope that these spring toppers will stay up for all to enjoy.

title: county-msp-gives-backing-campaign-scrap-benefits-cap
story: In January, anti-poverty champions launched a campaign demanding the UK Government scrap their “unjust” benefits cap. Nearly  groups, led by the Poverty Alliance, said they believed the policy hit lone parents and ethnic minorities the hardest.The cap was introduced in .For families in Scotland, social security payments are limited to a maximum of £, a month.The cap works by reducing either housing benefit or Universal Credit.Critics of the cap say the policy has compounded poverty and has reinforced negative stereotypes about benefits claimants.They say that a large chunk of the welfare budget ends up in the pockets of landlords, rather than to those in most need.Commenting on the campaign, county MSP Paul McLennan said: “The way that the benefit cap is enforced means those requiring the highest level of support from the benefit system – such as lone parents with young children, larger families, and people who are not able to work – are the most likely to be affected."I am backing the Scrap the Cap campaign because it is unfair, unjust and it is tightening the grip of poverty on families up and down the country.”

title: nasty-gal-zara-pink-dress-went-viral-tiktok-less---get

title: plans-lodged-90-homes-edge-elphinstone
story: The -hectare site on the village’s western edge could be the site of  houses and four flats.The proposed development, by Bellway Homes Scotland East, could also result in an expansion of Elphinstone Primary School.Plans have been lodged with East Lothian Council.Margo Macdonald, a member of Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council and the village’s community association, advised all those with thoughts on the proposals to get in touch with the local authority and share their views.The site, off the village’s Main Street and to the east of the football ground, was previously identied as suitable for housing in East Lothian Council’s Local Development Plan.Potential developers met with members of the public and held an exhibition in September .At that time, more than  people attended the public event and provided feedback on the proposals.Now, a more detailed version of the plans has been put forward.Nearly  homes are planned for the outskirts of Elphinstone. Picture: Gordon BellDrawings included in the application show that  three-bedroom homes and  four-bedroom homes would be created.The site could also provide  affordable properties.These would be a mix of two-bedroom cottage flats , two-bedroom mid terrace houses , three-bedroom end terrace houses , and four-bedroom end terrace houses .A design and access statement has been included as part of the planning application, which could be determined by the beginning of July.It outlines four “core objectives of the design”, including to “support a rich and pleasurable quality of le for inhabitants and visitors” and to “connect people and places by providing ease of movement within, and through developments”.The proposals also include a drawing which identies land to the east of the village’s primary school, which currently has a school roll of  and a further  in the nursery, for potential school expansion.Discussions would take place between Bellway Homes Scotland East and East Lothian Council surrounding a section  agreement for any expansion and other potential improvements in the village.

title: prestonpans-band-win-silver-scottish-brass-band-championships
story: Dalkeith and Monktonhall Brass Band took home silver at the Scottish Brass Band Championships – their first competition in over two years.The band, conducted by musical director James Chamberlain, competed against nine other bands in the first section of the contest, playing Spectrum by Gilbert Vinter.Heather Henderson, band secretary, said: “The band has really settled after the long months of the pandemic and are starting to reap the benefits of our new, larger premises in the Red School Youth Centre in Kirk Street.“This contest result at Perth brings an invitation to represent Scotland and compete at the National Brass Band Championships of Great Britain in September this year, which is held in Cheltenham.”James added: “We have a great team of players and administrators at the band who stepped up to the challenges.“Thanks to everyone for a great effort.”The last time the band performed Spectrum was in , under the direction of Alan Fernie, which won first place at the same contest.Alan was invited by the band toas a guest conductor and worked with James during the contest preparations in February.A busy summer season of concerts and other public appearances are in order for the band.Email Heather via secretarydmbrass@gmail with any queries about the band.

title: easter-big-top-circus-returns-east-lothian-spring
story: From Friday, April , to Sunday, April , visitors will be entertained by comedy circus performers in the baby big top as well as learning skills at the outside workshop.Circus shows are at am, pm and pm each day and each performance lasts around  minutes.Booking for adults and children aged three and over is essential by going to https:www.eventbrite e A £ car park charge applies to non National Trust for Scotland members.

title: dunbars-lauderdale-park-receives-new-gates-queens-platinum-jubilee
story: Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnershipand East Lothian Council have improved the gates at the entrance to Dunbar’s Lauderdale Park.Fitted with a crown mot, the gates tie in to the celebrations marking Queen Elizabeth II’s platinum jubilee.George Robertson, former chairman of DELAP, had previously raised concerns about the condition of the park’s gates.He said: “I alerted East Lothian Council to the problem with the gates.“All the gates were very heavily corroded and I was concerned a child may catch their clothing on it and some rusty bits were sticking out.“It was a safety issue as well as a cosmetic issue.”After discussions between members of DELAP, it was agreed that they would allocate £, towards the cost of the project.East Lothian Council amenities staff were at the park, which is between Bayswell Road and Parsonspool, earlier this month to put the new gates in place.

title: starbucks-ready-open-haddington
story: Sixteen jobs will be created at the drive-thru coffee shop, which is off Haddington’s West Road.To celebrate, the store will provide complimentary offers for the local community, ahead of the opening.Joe Baker, store manager, said: “We are excited to open our new drive-thru store in Haddington and look forward to welcoming the local community.“The team will continue to closely follow the latest guidance from both the government and health authorities to keep everyone safe.”" alt"East Lothian Courier: Starbucks is opening in Haddington tomorrow " class"editor-image"Starbucks is opening in Haddington tomorrowThe new coffee shop is open from .am Monday to Friday, am on Saturdays and .am on Sundays.It closes at pm each day.Starbucks is located next to Haddington Retail Park, which features Costa Coffee, The Food Warehouse, Aldi and Home Bargains.One unit remains vacant and a petrol station, with shop, is currently being built.

title: stone-stacking-championships-dunbar-set-expand-week-long-festival-year
story: The European Stone Stacking Championships have become a staple of Dunbar’s social calendar, with thousands of people visiting the town each year.Now, the event will be rebranded the European Land Art Festival and Stone Stacking Championships.James Craig Page, founder, is hoping to secure £, through a crowdfunder campaign to enhance the programme.He said: “It will mean we will be able to develop the European Stone Stacking Championships from a two or three-day festival into a week-long nature, art and environmentally aware festival.“We are very blessed in Dunbar to have such an amazing iety of beaches and woodland areas.“All these dferent areas can be used in workshops and developing artwork using dferent materials found in this area.“They make a perfect backdrop for a town-wide festival and we are looking forward to bringing thousands of people to Dunbar this year from all around the world.”: European Stone Stacking Championships in Dunbar a big successFunding from Dunbar Community Council means artists will be able to stay in the town’s Dolphin Inn.Previously, the championships were centred on Eye Cave Beach, near Dunbar Leisure Pool.Now it is hoped the event, which will take place from July  to , will be spread across four new locations – The Backlands, off the town’s High Street Dunbar Harbour Belhaven Beach and Lochend Woods – as well as Eye Cave Beach.Plans show mosaic making, a woodland walk and sand art, as well as the stone stacking championships, which will be split into ious categories.Mr Page, who lives in the town, stressed that without the funding there would still be a version of the event going ahead. However, he hoped securing the money would result in the full programme.He highlighted the physical and mental health benefits of getting back to nature, with more people embracing the outdoors during the Covid- pandemic.He said: “We have to take positives from this situation.“More than ever, people need nature and to be outdoors and communicating with each other, sharing stories and concerns, and looking forward to a brighter future.”In , before the pandemic, the event attracted about , people and Mr Page was hopeful of a record-breaking year.He said: “I would estimate we could easily take that to , visitors this year.”See crowdfunder p europeanstonestacking for more information.

title: womens-aid-services-east-lothian-open-waiting-lists-lockdown
story: A report by the two counties’ joint public protection committee has revealed that, while the number of reported domestic violence incidents fell, the level of help victims needed rose.And the impact meant that at one point the service had about  women waiting three months to be given access to the help they needed.Kirsty MacDiarmid, public protection manager for East and Midlothian, said that the service made sure there was some weekly contact with every victim waiting to be assigned a key worker.She said: “Covid provided opportunities for perpetrators of abuse and it was very dficult for people to make reports of domestic abuse during that period.“What we are seeing in the police reports is only the tip of the iceberg and a victim will have experienced previous incidents and it can be months and maybe years of abuse before they make a report.”The charity report said that, between April  and March , , domestic abuse incidents were recorded by police in East Lothian – down eight per centon the previous year.In Midlothian, , incidents were recorded – down . per cent .But the report, presented to East Lothian Council’s policy and performance committee last week, said that the numbers did not truly represent the pressures on the service.It said: “The impact of the Covid pandemic on domestic abuse saw increased opportunities for perpetrators to exert coercive control, and concerns for the increased invisibility of victims and perpetrators during lockdown.“Heightened levels of trauma and isolation will have longstanding impacts and we have seen the impact on the women, children and young people who have sought support.“Women’s Aid East and Midlothianhad to open waiting lists for longer-term support for the first time ever, which reached three months’ waiting time for support for more than  women.“This was exacerbated when the Domestic Abuse Service, which provides short-term intensive support for survivors at highest risk, reached its full capacity and had to refer on to WAEML services.”Councillor Colin McGinn said: “I am struck by the figures. I think the men in our county need to take a look at themselves.”

title: easter-bunny-coming-cockenzie-house-next-month
story: On Easter Saturday and Sunday, April  and , from am to pm, the house and gardens will host the fluffy bunny and a woodland trail. A craft sale, open studios and food will also be on offer.Tickets cost £ per child and must be booked in advance at Cockenzie House.

title: volunteers-sought-beach-clean-dunbars-east-beach
story: From Belhaven to Blyth, hundreds of people will pick up litter on their local bit of coast.Attendees at the clean-up, which takes place from am to noon, should bring gardening or work gloves.

title: weekend-cardiac-screening-memory-young-cycling-champion-ben-forsyth
story: Ben Forsyth was diagnosed with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathyin  and passed away on July , .The -year-old, a former Musselburgh Grammar School pupil and member of Edinburgh Road Clubcycling club, won the British youth circuit race championship in .He was studying geography at the University of Edinburgh at the time of his death.Cardiac Risk in the Youngwas due to hold screenings in East Lothian two years ago but all appointments were cancelled due to the Covid- pandemic.CRY offers subsidised ECGscreening to all young people between the ages of  and .Now, the Forsyth family have confirmed that three days of screenings will take place in April in Prestonpans and Berwick.Ben’s dad Keith said in a statement on Facebook: “After the disappointment of the cancelled CRY screening days over the last two years, we are delighted to announce that we have three days of screenings coming up in April.“This is the result of all the fantastic fundraising efforts of many family and friends over the past three-and-a-half years in memory of our amazing Ben.“A huge thank you to those who have supported and donated.”Two days of screenings will take place on April  and  at Preston Lodge High School, and a further day of screening will take place on April  at Berwick Rugby Club in Berwick-upon-Tweed.Visit testmyheart.org.uk for more information.

Openreach will be clearing a blockage and a rope duct on Tantallon Road, near the entrance to Tantallon Caravan Park.The work will take place between .am and .pm and will require a three-way temporary signal and additional signage.The scheduled works will last for one working day.An Openreach spokesperson said: "This work is scheduled to go ahead tomorrow, with traffic management booked for one day."It’s needed to clear a blockage from an underground duct which will house a high-bandwidth cable."We’re sorry for any inconvenience to drivers while the traffic lights are in place."Borderlink will also be conducting duct section tests on Tantallon Road between the entrance to Tesco and the junction with Rhodes Park.The work is expected to start between March  and March  and will last for three working days.

title: section-a1-slip-road-closed-several-nights
story: Works to improve drainage along . kilometres southbound carriageway of the A between Old Craighall and Bankton is set to be completed over three nights beginning next Wednesday.The final section of the works will see Transport Scotland’s operating company BEAR Scotland improve  metres of filter drain between Dolphingstone and Bankton.During these works, the slip road onto the southbound A at Dolphingstone Junction will be closed between .pm and am next Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.A signed ersion route will be in place for southbound traffic wishing to join the A at Dolphingstone, via the A, B and A to rejoin the A at Bankton Junction.This will add an estimated seven minutes and . miles to affected journeys.Traffic travelling on the A southbound prior to the Dolphingstone on slip will remain unaffected.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotland’s South East Network Manager, said: “These drainage improvements will improve safety for motorists using this section of the A.“It’s necessary for us to close the slip road to complete the job, however we’ve scheduled the works at night to minimise disruption.”Real time journey information is available from Traffic Scotland on www.trafficscotland.org, twitter at @trafficscotland or the mobile site my.trafficscotland.org

title: council-leader-makes-request-off-the-kerb-recycling-collections
story: Councillor Norman Hampshire, leader of East Lothian Council, made the request at a virtual meeting of the councils planning committee earlier this week.But his call for the developer to consider making an off-street space for people to put out their bins was quickly dismissed by council officers, who said that the point of a kerbside collection was the rubbish being left at the kerb.Mr Hampshire, who is convenor of the planning committee, asked a representative of Mactaggart and Mickel, which is building homes in the Letham Mains development, Haddington,they had been asked by customers for help with recycling.The council recently introduced a weekly kerbside recycling service after adding a fourth recycling receptacle to the household collections.Under the new regime, a food waste bin, two separate boxes for glass and paper card, and a white bag for plastic and cartons, are collected one day a week.Household waste bins are collected fortnightly on a separate day and garden waste bins remain on a monthly collection.: East Lothian Councils new recycling scheme launchedMr Hampshire asked the developer: “Would there be a design within your proposal so people had somewhere to put these boxes at the front of their property for collection on collection day “Everybody now does it,you drive round that estate on collection day you’ll see these boxes andthey are on the footpath itself it can cause an obstruction.“If there was at least a space at the front garden where these could be laid then it would certainly be a big help to the local authority and what we are trying to achieve and to your customers when they buy your properties.”Mr Hampshire asked Mr Hampton to take the request back to his firm as something to consider for future developments.However, a spokesman for East Lothian Council said that the current policy would need to be changed and approved by councillors before collections could be made from people’s gardens.A spokesperson said: “Waste services guidance requires developers to create storage for waste and recycling containers within the boundary of each property.“Collections, however, are operated on the basis of presentation at the kerbside.“A change in policy would require wider discussion between council departments and ratication at committee level.”

title: wordle-268-todays-wordle-word-14-march-hints-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you’re still trying to save your streak, then don’t scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today’s word starts with the letter S and ends with the letter T.It has one vowel.What is today’s Wordle answer, Monday, March  If you have given up on today’s game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now. The Wordle for March  is SMELT. The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: “Since launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.“The game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .“It has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me – from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.“On the flip side, I’d be lyingI said this hasn’t been overwhelming.“After all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.“Given this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that I’ve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.”
