title: injury marrs shinty return as newtonmore defender requires surgery after blow to the
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineFowler appeared to be knocked out after taking a blow to the head in the closing seconds of the game.The injury would require surgery in Aberdeen on Sunday morning, after the player was transfered from Raigmore in Inverness on Saturday evening. An update on the player#s condition # which suggested he suffered a skull fracture # was shared on the Newtonmore Camanachd Facebook site on Sunday afternoon.Fowler had helped his team to a - victory over last year#s Camanachd and MacTavish Cup winners.Iain Robinson got the opening goal after  minutes, rling in at the back post after a corner from the impressive winger Drew MacDonald.Jordan Fraser swept home a Keith MacRae cross to level matters on  minutes, but Max Campbell restored the visitors# lead in the nd minute, and veteran Fraser MacKintosh netted from long range just before half time to put Newtonmore # who were without Mike Russell and Craig Ritchie due to Covid # in command.The lack of pre-season action looked as though it had taken its toll, and Shiel never found their rhythm in a fragmented second half interupted by injuries.#More attacker Iain Robinson suffered a dislocated shoulder, a back problem forced off Shiel striker John MacRae, while defender David Falconer#s afternoon was ended early by a hamstring problem.Kinlochshiel manager Johnston Gill said: #We never reached half the level we did last season, and against a team like Newtonmore that isn#t enough.#We can play better, and we will play better as we get more games under our belts, but it#s a disappointing start to lose at home.#Newtonmore co-manager Norman MacArthur was delighted at his team#s display # with Steven MacDonald and Rory Kennedy outstanding in defence.He said: #We came over with no expectations # but the young boys who came in were fantastic. To get our season underway with a win at the Scottish champions is a great way to start.#ELSEWHERE ON SATURDAY, Mowi Premier League champions Kingussie got off to a flyer with Savio Genini scoring four in a - home rout of Caberfeidh.Lovat and Oban Camanachd each recorded - away wins at Kilmallie and Glasgow Mid Argyll respectively, while Kyles Athletic recovered from two down to salvage a - draw with Fort William at An Aird.In the National Division Skye Camanachd fell behind to a Daniel MacMillan strike after  minutes, but goals from Jordan Murchison on  and John Gillies on  minutes proved enoough to earn the islanders victory against Oban Celtic.Euan MacCormick scored four as Beauly set the pace in the ision by putting nine without reply past Aberdour.Lochaber edged Strathglass by the odd goal in five at Cannich, while Inveraray and Glenurquhart shared the points after a - draw at the Winterton.

title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person’s parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary – not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection “a genuine product of the past” with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‘blood is thicker than water’, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance – strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly – we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex Gàidhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much –not more – influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the Gàidhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‘mycelium’ of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream – the carrying stream – slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: new road safety works welcomed
story: ROAD safety works on A Carnlough Road will be welcomed by local residents says Cllr. Beth Adger.The works will take place between Aghacully Road and Hazelbank Road and will involve the creation of a high friction surface.Cllr. Adger said a deputation from Aughafatten area residents had told her of their fears about speeding in the area.They were fearful that accidents were on the increase and were pleading for something to be done to eradicate the problem.I sought the support of DFIand I’m delighted to receive this week a positive response from them. Work will begin on March .She added: With a long history of proven success in improving road safety and saving lives, high friction surfacing benefits both road users and pedestrians, particularly in dangerous conditions such as adverse weather.High friction surfacing is a material and a process by which road surfaces become less prone to skidding and loss of friction. Instead of a smooth and slippery surface, high friction surfacing creates thousands of tiny contact points, known as a micro-texture. This means that a vehicle’s tyres have more contact with the road, allowing them to better grip the surface and come to a safer stop.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220318newsgoods for ni won t be able to get in after p o temporarily halt larne sailings
story: Supplies coming into Northern Ireland will almost certainly be affected by the decision by PO to temporarily halt sailings at Larne Port as other ferry operators are “pretty near full”. That’s according to Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots, who was speaking after the ferry operator sacked  staff yesterday. It could be another week before the firm’s ships will be able to operate again and Mr Poots has warned that goods normally coming here wont be able to get in. There are export materials that need to get out of Northern Ireland which wont get out. About % of our food is exported out of Great Britain, so that is a real problem for us, he told BBC NIs The View. Meanwhile the Infrastructure Minister, Nichola Mallon MLA, has expressed her concern at the actions by PO Ferries and the impact locally. The Minister said: I was shocked to hear the news from PO Ferries this morning and my thoughts are with those staff working for PO who have lost their jobs and also with those whose travel has been disrupted. This is a developing situation and officials are working on a cross-departmental basis to assess any local impacts, especially for supply chains, and are keeping in close contact with their counterparts in the Department of Transport in London. With the Economy Minister I am calling on the Secretary of State for Transport to take every possible step to save jobs and to maintain connectivity for passengers and freight on Irish Sea routes.

Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium BBC’s Emma Vardy is on the crest of a wave... and set to tie the knot at Co Antrim fairytale castleBBC journalist will be married next SaturdayExpandExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEmma Vardy with bridesmaids on her hen night. Credit: Ernie Saese PhotographerErnie Saese PhotographerEmma Vardy enjoying a day’s surfingEmma Vardy with fiance Aaron AdamsEmma with future stepson Jonah FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEmma Vardy with bridesmaids on her hen night. Credit: Ernie Saese PhotographerClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailHere is an exclusive that Emma Vardy hasn’t broadcast yet — she is getting married next Saturday.And the BBC Ireland Correspondent — who will doubtless look every inch the fairytale princess on her wedding day — could not be happier.She has got the venue she always wanted — an ancient castle in Co Antrim — and the photographer she had always hoped would be available to capture the big day.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEmma Vardy with fiance Aaron Adams FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEmma Vardy with fiance Aaron AdamsMost of all, however, she will be tying the knot with the man of her dreams, Aaron Adams, whose nine-year-old son Jonah will be the ring bearer.After that, it’s off to Hawaii and the other love of her le — surfing — in those legendary Pacic waves.“We chose Lissanoure Castle for our wedding because it’s a beautul venue in lovely grounds,” Emma told the Belfast .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “I just thought that every great fairytale has to have a castle in it.“It’s a little bit like something out of a Disney movie — beautul castle walls, stunning grounds, lovely log fires.“An added bonus is that it’s very near the north coast, so there’s surf nearby…”The -year-old revealed that she will be wearing a “traditional white dress” on March , but other details remain classied.“I’ve kept it really secret from Aaron so he doesn’t know anything about it so that’s going to be a big surprise on the day,” she told his newspaper.The couple, who have been together for almost three years, always wanted a spring wedding. “I really love spring time,” Emma said.“It’s always been a favourite time of the year for me. The evenings are getting brighter, the daffodils are coming up, you start to feel that excitement in the air of summer ahead...”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEmma Vardy enjoying a day’s surfing FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEmma Vardy enjoying a day’s surfingAlthough the Southampton native considered celebrating her nuptials on the south coast of England, she chose to stay here instead after careful consideration.“I really wanted all the people I care about to come to Northern Ireland,” she said.“It just seemed right to have it here because Northern Ireland is also where I’m really proud to call home. I’ve got lots of family and friends coming over — the north coast is going to be packed out with English people over that weekend.”The ceremony will take place in the grounds of the th century venue near Loughguile, with the reception in the castle itself.It’s going to be a “pretty sizeable” affair, with  guests during the day and “loads more” in the evening.“There’ll be an interesting blend of guests, from surfing friends and media to people we play football with,” she said.The bride, groom and their guests are all staying in Ballycastle,  miles away. “I love waking up and seeing the sea,” Emma said.“We’re all going to go for a walk on the beach the next day and hang out.“People are coming for three or four days so we’re going to spend time together on the north coast before and after and I’ll get to show people the real Northern Ireland.”The photographer is award-winning Ballymoney man Kris Dickson, who was always Emma’s first — or rather only — choice.“It was obviously meant to be because when I spoke to Kris it just happened that that date was the only Saturday he had free between now and Christmas,” she said.Emma will have four bridesmaids — two best friends from England and two cousins. The newlyweds will then head off on honeymoon to the Hawaiian islands for nearly three weeks on Monday, March .“It’s always been my dream to go there,” she said.“We’re going to surf as much as possible, and in between that we’re probably going to climb a few mountains or volcanos.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseEmma with future stepson Jonah FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEmma with future stepson JonahAarondoesn’t have Emma’s  years’ surfing experience, but he’s “doing really well” learning all about wipeouts, leggies and cutbacks.He proposed to her on terra firma, at the top of Cave Hill. Although the couple went there several times a week during lockdown, they had never watched the sun rise on the mountain.“We got there before first light and walked up just in time to see it,” said Emma, an adrenalin junkie who started learning how to play gaelic football and camogie last winter.“We sat at the summit. It was really cold and dark and icy blue first of all and then the whole sky changed to gold and orange and purple as the sun peaked over the horizon.“While we were watching this incredible light show Aaron turned to me and popped the question.“He got down on one knee, with an incredibly beautul diamond ring.“It couldn’t have been more perfect.”Emma recently presented her first BBC’s Newsnight programme and are other working assignments she’d like to consider. “It would be great to cover American politics,” she said.The story in Europe is also going to be fascinating for years to come in the aftermath of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.”Luckily, Aaron is ready to pack his bags and follow her to the ends of the earth. “I’m really lucky. We make a great team. He’s so supportive. “I know that’s not always easy,” she said.“He’s excited and up for whatever the future holds.”Most ReadSchools’ Cup Final: Ben McFarlane the Methody hero as superb second-half title: economy minister gordon lyons rules out financial support to help people working from home
story: Economy Minister Gordon Lyons. Credit: Liam McBurney FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEconomy Minister Gordon Lyons. Credit: Liam McBurneyAndrew MaddenTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailEconomy Minister Gordon Lyons has ruled out providing financial support for those facing increased costs as a result of working from homedue to the pandemic.Instead, Mr Lyons said he is focusing on encouraging more people toto their places of work safely and on broader economic recovery.Due to the pandemic, tens of thousands of people here moved to WFH home during lockdown, with the practice still continuing for many as we move out of the health crisis.A recent report by Ulster University#s Economic Policy Centrefound that two-thirds of those who switched to WFH during lockdown want flexible working arrangements to continue into the future.The research also found that between -% would prefer to notto the office at all, with the majority instead favouring a #hybrid# working arrangement, which would see them ing to the office for between two and four days a week.Prior to Covid, less than % of people worked from home regularly, but during the first lockdown in April , this figure increased to %. Currently, the proportion of NI employees working from home remains at over %.As things stand, official government guidance states you should continue to work from home, where possible, with employers required to facilitate staff to do so.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Some employers are providing workers with additional money to cover the cost of heating, electricity and other expenditures incurred while working from home, however in recent months these costs have spiralled.Green Party MLA Rachel Woods said: “We are in the midst of a cost-of-living crisis and the five-party Executive is failing to protect those most affected in our society.There’s emergency funding which cannot be spent because of the collapse of the Executive. The DUP should re-nominate a First Minister to enable this money to be spent to help those struggling because of the rising cost of fuel, including those who are facing higher costs because they have to work at home.“Longer term, the Economy Minister must consider options for those who will continue to work from home, given the impact of the pandemic and shts in working patterns. It’s time for politicians to do their jobs and deliver for Northern Ireland.”Alliance Party economy spokesperson Stewart Dickson said: “We are not out of the pandemic yet. There are many positives which have emerged from working from home for people, including increased productivity and an improved work-le balance.Any massto offices would see many people hit by increased travel costs. Employers by now should have learned the lessons from home working and the Department for the Economy should provide a wide range of guidance to them, in order to encourage people to continue working from homenecessary and required.”People Before Profit MLA Gerry Carroll said, given that the virus is still circulating and many employers are facilitating flexible working he finds it “astounding that the Minister responsible for workers has put nothing in place and has shrugged his shoulders to the extra costs people are faced with at this moment.”“People are working home for a number of reasons and are experiencing higher bills due to the nature of energy prices shooting up,” he said.It’s unacceptable that workers are forced to stomach these costs. People did what was asked of them during the pandemic- the least the government can do now is to stick by those workers who are financially struggling when working from home. The fact that they haven’t is a catastrophic failure on the Minister’s part.”Related topicsGordon LyonsRachel WoodsStewart DicksonDepartment for the EconomyMore On Gordon LyonsPO will not operate Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Northern Ireland power station wants to ditch Russian coal — but Stormont says noSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailOne of Northern Ireland’s main power stations wants to stop buying Russian coal — but is forced to do so by Stormont’s licence requirements.A huge shipment of Russian coal arrived in Belfast Harbour at the weekend using a vessel registered in the Marshall Islands to transport the consignment to Belfast Harbour, meaning it was landed without breaking the UK’s sanctions regime.On Tuesday much of the shipment was still visible in the harbour. Kilroot power station said that shipment was not for it, and it last brought in Russian coal on th February. The power station, which dominates the northern shoreline of Belfast Lough just east of Carrickfergus, is our last coal-fired electricity generation plant and is due to close next year.Read MoreUkrainian refugee scheme: Vital that sponsors in Northern Ireland are properly checked, warns anti-slavery expertUp to £m of RHI money may go unspent by StormontHowever, it is still key to keeping the lights on, and has been called upon more in recent years due to problems at other power stations and unusually calm days reducing wind power generation.Coal was Russia’s third most valuable export by value in , bringing in £.bn. Northern Ireland was the only UK region to see coal-fired electricity generation increase that year, accounting for % of all electricity.Energy imports from Russia have not been banned, but have come under scrutiny due to revulsion at Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine and the escalation of the war through the targeting of civilians.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Kilroot’s position appears similar to that of Shell, which bought Russian oil — entirely legally — days into the Ukraine war, but backtracked under huge public pressure and promised not to do so again.Read MoreMalachi O#Doherty:OpinionMy utility bills now cost £ a week. Pensioners are in big troubleHowever, Kilroot’s situation is complicated by what it says is a requirement in its licence to buy Russian coal for environmental reasons, because it is low-sulphur, and thus somewhat reduces air pollution when burned.!forfort[r].style.e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"When Stormont’s Department for the Economy, which is responsible for electricity policy, was askedit believed environmental rules should be relaxed to allow Kilroot to burn dirtier coal, it initially washed its hands of the matter, saying: “The department does not have responsibility for environmental rules. This is the responsibility of DAERA Northern Ireland Environment Agency .”That answer came despite the RHI Inquiry recommending Stormont stopped operating in silos and behaved coherently as a single government entity.However, Kilroot’s owner then told the Belfastit had been meeting the department, NIEA, electricity grid operator SONI and the Utility Regulator to discuss this issue since the crisis began. That was put to the Department for the Economy and to Edwin Poots’ Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, which is responsible for NIEA.But there was no response at the time of going to press.EP Kilroot, a subsidiary of Czech company Energetický, which owns the plant, said it “condemns the indefensible aggression and actions by Russia”.It added that it “complies with all UK sanctions and associated regulations in relation to Russia”, and stressed there were “signicant stock levels of coal on the Kilroot site at present”.It said: “We have contingency plans in place for alternative sources of coal supply. “This plan requires changing EP Kilroot’s permit, which currently prevents us from using coals from other countries.“Since the start of the Ukraine crisis, EP Kilroot has chaired a number of roundtable workshops with officials from DfE, NIEA, the Utility Regulator and SONI to urgently address the issues of the current permitting arrangements to enable EP Kilroot to remove its reliance on Russian coal.“If the permitting arrangements are not changed, we believe there will be signicant security of supply risks that SONI will need to manage.”The company claimed there could also be “signicant additional costs” for consumers “depending on the extent to which the coal units are restricted”.When DfE, headed by DUP minister Gordon Lyons, was asked for its view on whether Kilroot should continue to buy Russian coal, the department expressed no preference, and said: “The purchase of coal is a commercial decision taken by EP Kilroot. However, the department will follow the guidance that has been issued by the UK Government in relation to Russian imports.”When asked how much coal stocks were in place at Kilroot, DfE said “this is not a matter for the department”, but SONI would tell itthere was a problem. When asked how much secondary fuel was stored at Kilroot, DfE said that was a matter for the company.SONI said it was “unaware of any immediate risk to coal stock at Kilroot”. It said inspection of fuel stocks was “not a matter for SONI”. It added Kilroot “has a key role to play in the energy transition”, involving the current generators as well as new gas turbines.Belfast Harbour said it was “working closely with shipping agents and relevant partners to implement all of the Government’s legislative sanctions on Russian vessels”, but it would only bar vessels excluded by law, rather than go further.The Utility Regulator said Kilroot was responsible for ensuring it held adequate fuel stocks. It added: “In light of the ongoing situation in Ukraine, we are working with DfE to proactively monitor the situation, and are engaging with EP Kilroot and other key stakeholders on a regular basis about fuel stocks and fuel security arrangements.”Overall imports of coal have generally been falling, but have risen to the point where they are now roughly where they were in , despite the reduction in the use of coal for home-heating and electricity generation.Irish state-owned electricity company ESB said it will not be taking delivery of Russian coal to its Moneypoint power station in Co Clare “for the foreseeable future”. It was reported that members of staff at the River Shannon facility had expressed concerns to management about accepting Russian coal in the current circumstances.On Monday, Andrei Melnichenko, owner of Russia’s biggest coal producer, said publicly that the war in Ukraine was a tragedy that must be stopped.Most ReadSchools’ Cup Final: Ben McFarlane the Methody hero as superb second-half comeback title: northern ireland woman who paid 600 for heating oil that wasnt delivered finally
story: Customer: Catherine Hughes who paid for oil that was never delivered. Credit: Liam McBurney RazorpixLiam McBurney RAZORPIX FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueCustomer: Catherine Hughes who paid for oil that was never delivered. Credit: Liam McBurney RazorpixClaire McNeillyTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA woman who paid £ for home heating oil that was never delivered has finally been reimbursed.Catherine Hughes, from south Belfast, was contacted by BoilerJuice after the Belfastreported that her order of  litres, which was made in February, failed to arrive.She subsequently had to pay another firm £ to have her tank filled or go without heating, after her oil ran out.Now, however, the matter has been resolved, with the supplier reimbursing her in full earlier this week.“The money was put back into my account on Tuesday,” she told this newspaper.Read MoreNI woman’s anger after paying £ for heating oil that hasn’t been delivered“I’m really happy about that but obviously the replacement order for the same amount of oil cost nearly £ more than I was originally supposed to pay.”Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Ms Hughes, who works in human resources, told how she’d been trying in vain to get in touch with the supplier after her home heating oil delivery, scheduled to arrive at the start of the following month, never came.“I placed an order on February  and was told to expect it on March ,” she said.“When it didn’t arrive I emailed the company but I couldn’t reach anyone. Then, when my oil ran out, I had no option but to place another order with a dferent company. By that stage, prices had soared and I was forced to pay £ for  litres.”She added: “BoilerJuice contacted me last Saturday, which is when the article appeared in the Belfast , they have now reimbursed me in full for the oil I didn’t get.“They also apologised for what happened.”BoilerJuice has been contacted for comment.Read MoreHome heating oil price in Northern Ireland drops by .% but Consumer Council warns it could be short-livedTrading Standards Service told the Belfastthat it had “received a high volume of calls” about the non-delivery of domestic home heating oil from a number of suppliers over the last week.“The Trading Standards Service’s consumer advice helpline, Consumerline, has received a high volume of calls about price increases in domestic home heating oil and non-delivery,” said Damien Doherty.“Most complainants allege that they have been quoted a price and paid for home heating on the day of the order and are subsequently informed that the price has increased signicantly on the day of delivery.“Consumers are then notied that they must pay the higher price or the order cancelled.”TSS said it will be contacting domestic home heating oil retailers “brought to our attention to make them aware of their obligations under consumer protection law in relation to the sale of home heating oil and to ensure that they treat their customers fairly”.The spokesman said thata domestic home heating oil retailer or online broker enters into an agreement for an order of oil with an agreed price and accepts payment then it’s a legally binding contract.“If the oil is not then delivered, this is likely to amount to a breach of contract,” said the spokesman.“Quoting a price and taking payment on the day of order and then charging a higher price on the day of delivery is also likely to amount to a breach of contract.“If a consumer wants to argue that there has been a breach of contract then, legally, they can pursue redress in the small claims court or contact their card provider to seek a refund or damages.”In response to an email sent by this newspaper, BoilerJuice said: “Due to unprecedented demand in the fuel industry, we are experiencing higher than usual customer contact. We apologise in the delay. Please expect a response within the next - working days.”Related topicsCost of LivingMore On Cost of LivingRevealed: Northern Ireland heating oil costs per postcode fall in fortnight but still remain at high levelsChancellor must cut duty on fuel and ease burden of cost of living crisis, says Alliance MLA Stewart DicksonGreens urge Northern Ireland Executive to help Kilroot power station to stop title: p and o jobs cull leaves ferry users high and dry
story: Hauliers and passengers forced to alter plans after mass sackings see Larne-Cairnryan service suspendedExpand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseSacked PO staff and RMT members block the road leading to the Port of Dover. Credit: Gareth FullerPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSacked PO staff and RMT members block the road leading to the Port of Dover. Credit: Gareth FullerJohn BreslinMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFreight operators and passengers were scrambling on Thursday night to switch plans following the sudden mass sacking of  PO Ferries employees, including dozens of skilled crew operating the Larne-Cairnryan route.The company announced the action via a video message, then sent private security staff — some wearing body armour and balaclavas, and carrying stun guns and handcuffs — to remove staff from the European Causeway docked in Larne.Sailings on the route are now suspended for at least five days and possibly a week, prompting concern over a serious disruption to the supply chain.Around  lorries use the route daily, many of them carrying perishable goods on what is the shortest Irish Sea crossing.Captains, engineers, electricians and other skilled deck and engine staff were sacked on Thursday, including around  operating the ferries between Scotland and here.They were immediately replaced by cheaper agency staff, unions said. Other workers, mostly hospitality and already employed through agencies, remained on board.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreThey have treated us all like c**p, says -year PO veteranMargaret Canning:OpinionPO Ferries: Operator of busy link with Scotland recorded £.m profit in , but other factors at play hereWhile PO was silent on Thursday night on why the services are suspended, it is believed the new crew needs to be trained up and may require the green light from maritime regulators to sail.Fears were growing among the approximately  to  Port of Larne ground staff employed directly by PO.East Antrim MLA John Stewart said they had heard nothing from the company as events unfolded quickly on Thursday, adding that the crew members were “treated despicably”.PO, owned by Dubai-headquartered conglomerate DP World since , said it had to take the action because the company was not “viable” after posting losses of £m in the last financial year.The sackings came two years after , staff were made redundant at the same time investors were paid a £m idend, which the company said it was legally obliged to disburse.“Our survival is dependent on making swt and signicant changes now. Without these changes there is no future for PO Ferries,” the company said.“These circumstances have resulted in a very dficult but necessary decision, which was only taken after seriously considering all the available options.”Unions representing the seafarers told members to stay on board, but those stepping off the ship said they had little choice but to leave after being confronted by the security staff and warned they were trespassing, and that the redundancy package would be withdrawnthey did not do so.Local politicians reacted with shock at the developments. It also caught industry insiders completely by surprise.East Antrim MP Sammy Wilson, who spoke with chief executive Peter Hebblethwaite, said he was assured the jobs of ground staff at Larne were secure, but added he was “appalled” at the treatment of the seafarers.“The way in which staff were removed from the ships is totally unacceptable and is not how any employer should treat their employees,” Mr Wilson said.“Despite operating purely between UK ports, PO will now be paying Third World wages to their crew.“This raises serious concerns about the company’s morality.”Immediate clarication is needed over the future of Larne Harbour, East Antrim Alliance MLA Stewart Dickson said.“Given PO owns Larne Harbour, urgent questions now need asked as to the potentially vast impact locally,” Mr Dickson said.Passengers, hauliers and cargo are being redirected to Stena Line ferries, with the company saying it is trying to accommodate but is extremely busy. It confirmed it was trying to accommodate those booked on the PO ferries between Scotland and Northern Ireland.“Most freight companies have accounts with all ferry operators and they are doing what they normally do during periods of disruptions and move via alternative routes operators where space is available,” Stena Line said.Logistics UK, the trade body for freight transport, warned there will be disruption but that those in the business of moving goods were flexible and used to quickly switching methods, either using other ferries or,needs be, air transport.But Seamus Leheny of the organisation said: “This has just come out of the blue... really shocked the industry.”Rail, Maritime and Transportunion general secretary Mick Lynch said: “We are seeking urgent legal action and are again calling for the Government to take action to stop what is fast turning into one of the most shameful acts in the history of British industrial relations.”Tom Long of law firm Shakespeare Martineau said: “PO’s decision to fire  staff with immediate effect appears to contravene the requirements needed for a normal mass redundancy.”Related topicsJohn StewartAlliance PartyStewart title: the co down couple sharing the joys of life on the farm
story: Malini and Iain Colville of Glenside Farm opened up to the community during the pandemic.ExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseMalini and Iain Colville on their farm near Co Down.Iain and Malini have run their farm for six years nowIain juggles the everyday needs of the farm with his work as a barrister FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMalini and Iain Colville on their farm near Co Down.Allan PrestonTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA Co Down farm with prize-winning cattle has offered the chance to escape everyday le by opening up to the community and offering respite to groups facing struggles, such as refugees and foster children.Married couple Malini and Iain Colville have been running Glenside Farm near Comber for six years.Their prize-winning livestock include Blue Texel sheep and Aberdeen Angus cattle, who are no strangers to winning rosettes at the Balmoral Show.While Iain is from a farming background in Newtownards, Malini grew up in London and has embraced the switch from city le to the peaceful countryside of Co Down.During the pandemic, they made the decision to also become a community farm and offer respite days for groups, including refugees.Great to have @ruralsupportni visit Glenside Farm this morning and the opportunity to feed the pet lambs born yesterday. Planning what the next few months will entail as we are getting ready for social farming. #socialfarming #ruralsupportni #southeasterntrust #belfasttrust pic PUFoUisKM— Glenside Farm ComberJanuary , For those facing struggles in their own le, it’s easy to see the attraction of escaping the city for a day to work outside, surrounded by green fields or even just sitting for a cup of tea and a chat with others.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Until recently, Malini had been working as the Northern Ireland lead of the fostering and adoption charity, Home for Good.She has now made the jump to focusing on the community farm project full-time.Iain also juggles the everyday needs of the farm with his work as a barrister.During lockdown, Malini said she often heard media reports about how access to rural spaces were important for mental health.We just thought we’d go on a bit of a journey about how we could use our farm,” she told the Belfast .After attending a community farming course, they signed up as a social farm.Typically, social farms will work with people who may have learning disabilities or mental health needs.Working alongside a farmer for the day, it helps to improve their wellbeing and to feel included in the community. Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseIain and Malini have run their farm for six years now FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIain and Malini have run their farm for six years nowMalini and Iain were keen to incorporate their own previous experience working with the refugee and asylum-seeking community in Northern Ireland.Malini said: We’d love to explore how to get families who may be living in a one bedroom flat in Belfast, who feel quite isolated, how to get them on to the farm.Another area they are keen to include is the fostering and adoption community.This can include bringing siblings together who are living in dferent homes.We’re just exploringI#m honest, a lot of it’s about finding the right funding and people who are going to support us,” she said.In the future, the couple are keen to expand further and invite out school groups.There could also be scope here for things like glamping for foster families, a space they can feel safe in.“We had Syrian refugee women on the farm a couple of weeks ago. One of them was actually a shepherdess in Syria, so she was asking my husband loads of questions.There’s beautul views down here, and she said to us ‘That’s what Syria would have looked like before the war’.That just shows the therapeutic power of doing this.Another lady who was part of that group was , she just sat by the woodburner to keep warm and have a cup of tea.But it was nice for her just to have a dferent space to relax in.”With the likelihood that some of those displaced from the current war in Ukraine will come to Northern Ireland, Malini said projects like Glenside Farm could offer friendship.“For these families that are displaced and come to Northern Ireland, or even foster families, they’re doing it alone,” she said.So being able to come to our farm can offer a sense of community.”Iain said that while the enterprise was still starting out, the couple were excited for its potential.Following lockdown, we realised that people in urban areas needed to be out and about for their mental health,” he said.We thought we have a lovely setting and quality animals for people to come out and enjoy being around.“We realised we could use the farm for other peoples’ benefits, a social enterprise that would facilitate access.Still maintaining a career as a barrister in London, Iain says he is amazed that he manages to keep everything going.It’s still early days, we’ve established the enterprise and Malini is taking the lead on developing programmes.It’s exciting now that she’s able to develop this full time, to facilitate access for vulnerable children and adults.”Most ReadSchools’ Cup Final: Ben McFarlane the Methody hero as superb second-half comeback earns them record th title with victory over CampbellHome heating oil price in Northern Ireland drops
